title_review: Great if you know what to get
review_preview: I can understand some of the hit and miss reviews below as some of the dishes we tried were not up to the usual Madrid standard. However be sure to try specialities such as their Patatas Bravas, Calimari and Croquettes. All some of the best...
review_full: I can understand some of the hit and miss reviews below as some of the dishes we tried were not up to the usual Madrid standard. However be sure to try specialities such as their Patatas Bravas, Calimari and Croquettes. All some of the best we had sampled in Madrid. This place is great for a quick pit stop in the afternoon to soak up the atmosphere at the bar. (rather than the usual over priced gran via haunt). For drinks be sure to ask for Cola y Limon where they will provide you with delicious lemon slushy which goes great with an ice cold coke. If you want to sit outside try the sister restaurant terrazzo de la reina around the corner. It has a more limited menu but some of the dishes are still available.

title_review: Memorable and well balanced tasting menu
review_preview: Dos Cielos was a superb experience from the setting and atmosphere, to the friendly service, to the creative and delicious food. Every dish had a unique flavor profile was artfully plated.  Hard to pick a favorite course since everything was different, but the fish dishes...
review_full: Dos Cielos was a superb experience from the setting and atmosphere, to the friendly service, to the creative and delicious food. Every dish had a unique flavor profile was artfully plated. Hard to pick a favorite course since everything was different, but the fish dishes (red mullet in a fish broth with carrot and potato “gnocchi”, and turbot with broccoli and cauliflower “caviar”) were superb, as was the creative honeycomb dessert. Wine pairings were reasonably priced and included cava and sherry in addition to whites and reds, an exceptional variety that complemented the meal without being excessive.  In my opinion, Dos Cielos is right up there with deserving a Michelin Star.

review_preview: My mom and I spent 2 weeks in southern Spain.  Our hotel recommended this restaurant as a good place for our last dinner in Spain.  When we first got there (7pm) they were open but we couldn't find anyone who worked there (waitress etc) so...
review_full: My mom and I spent 2 weeks in southern Spain. Our hotel recommended this restaurant as a good place for our last dinner in Spain. When we first got there (7pm) they were open but we couldn't find anyone who worked there (waitress etc) so we left and decided to come back later. We came back around 830. They made it seem like they were doing us a huge favor seating us without reservations. We were thankful they accommodated us. At no point during our 2 hour stay there did the place fill up. We asked the waiter for just an extra moment to decide our order. He disappeared for about 15 minutes. Been he reappeared, we ordered one glass of sangria, one water, and four tapas. Our sangria and two tapas came out quickly. The sangria tasted completely like syrup. It was awful. The fried fish and spinach pear salad were very good, though not unique. The two stars I give this place are for those two tapas The other two tapas did not come out until about a half hour after we finished the first two. By that point, we just wanted to be done. The last two tapas were eggplant and croquettes (two of my favorite tapas over our trip). They were pretty terrible. The eggplant was oddly prepared and the sauce way too overpowering. The croquettes seem like the type you buy in the frozen section of a supermarket, though saltier and mushier inside and not as tasty. We ate enough of each to say we were full and got the check. The check for one sangria, one water, four tapas was approx 45 euro!? Insane!! The pen would not work to sign the receipt but the girl did not get a new pen and said it did not matter if we signed or not. I am sorry our hotel would recommend people here. Interestingly enough, 100% of the clientele eating in the dining area were speaking English. This makes me think it is definitely a tourist trap.

title_review: So good, we ate here twice
review_preview: Our hotel concierge recommended this place to us for lunch when we first arrived from the airport.  We went at about 1:30 in the afternoon on a Thursday and the place was very crowded with business people taking their lunch breaks.  We managed to snag...
review_full: Our hotel concierge recommended this place to us for lunch when we first arrived from the airport. We went at about 1:30 in the afternoon on a Thursday and the place was very crowded with business people taking their lunch breaks. We managed to snag a table in the bar area and were pleasantly surprised with the wine and tapas selection. We have never been to Spain and only speak some basic Spanish but were able to order a good mix of meat, cheese and veggies. The wine they offered by the glass was tasty (we had Ribero del Duero) and went well with all of our tapas. The staff was busy and brief, but were helpful when we were attempting to order. We went back a few days later for another round for lunch. This time we sat at the bar and were able to watch what came out as others ordered. Overall a good lunch both times, would return if we are ever in Madrid again.

review_preview: Maybe should be about 4.5 stars, but I will give them the benefit of the doubt.  Location is right on the Via Grande, in an area where I wouldn't expect to find such good food.  Downstairs is a bustling tapas bar, and upstairs in the...
review_full: Maybe should be about 4.5 stars, but I will give them the benefit of the doubt. Location is right on the Via Grande, in an area where I wouldn't expect to find such good food. Downstairs is a bustling tapas bar, and upstairs in the back is a sit-down type of restaurant. Got there a bit early for the restaurant, so we started out with a glass of good cava and a few tapas. The tapas were pretty good, but the restaurant was excellent. The room has a kind of modern yet rustic feel to it. As for the food, the Secreto Iberico was great, as were the habas. A terrific bottle of wine and a couple of tasty shared desserts completed the meal. The service was good, and the staff friendly. I'll be back for sure.

review_preview: We visited this restaurant for the first (and in all likelihood last) time just before Christmas.  It is very pleasant although small – a foyer-like space with three small tables just as you enter, and a larger room further in, which when we were there...
review_full: We visited this restaurant for the first (and in all likelihood last) time just before Christmas. It is very pleasant although small – a foyer-like space with three small tables just as you enter, and a larger room further in, which when we were there was occupied by one large table for a group.  The place has considerable charm with bare brick walls and a nice décor. The food is excellent, although not necessarily very French. So far so good. Food portions were enormous, with a big appetizer on the house, so a great place to bring a hungry teenager, but way too large helpings to be “elegant” or even appetizing. As far from nouvelle cuisine as you can get.  The main problem, though, was the service which was bordering on rude. For instance, we were asked to keep our cutlery between the free appetizer and the next course, because we "were supposed to have eaten it with a spoon”. This appetizer, known as migas – a typically Spanish and tasty dish (in a “French” restaurant??) consisting of bread crumbs and a variety of other ingredients – was apparently meant to have been eaten from the plate it was served on with the two spoons that came with it, rather than from our individual plates as we did. And they bluntly refused to change the cutlery, although we were able to get new plates, after asking for it. Furthermore, the wine list is fairly limited to be a first-class French restaurant and the first two wines we ordered were not available. Finally the place is overpriced, not least the wines. Thus, to conclude, a small and cozy place in the heart of old Madrid, French in name only, with vast potential and excellent food, but suffering from unhelpful staff with over-inflated egos and ditto prices.

We found this tucked away little gem thanks to Frommer's guide. It is indeed as cozy and old world as the description we had read. The food was wonderful and quite sophisticated. What really made this so special, however, was the owner/ chef who greeted us, seated us, prepared our dinner and served us. According to Frommer's, the gentleman (and I mean true gentleman) is named Marcel Magossian. My suggestion: ask Mr. Magossian to make your dinner selections for you and then sit back and enjoy a delightful evening.

Salad, or to be specific, the dressing deserves it's own praise. I am not a big fan of leaves, but with their dressing I was tempted to lick the plate clean. So the only real choice is the level of steak doneness and the wine to assist the digest.  The place gets really busy, really fast and waiters (only 2 of them) do wonders to serve all.  With that, I recommend booking in advance. We got lucky (ignorance is a bliss), but considering the size of the place, it was a fools luck.

review_preview: To be honest, we were disappointed in this restaurant as I'd passed it many times on foot as it is in our neighborhood and quite close to where we live.   It looks good from the outside and does have nice decor.Unfortunately, the food did...
review_full: To be honest, we were disappointed in this restaurant as I'd passed it many times on foot as it is in our neighborhood and quite close to where we live. It looks good from the outside and does have nice decor. Unfortunately, the food did not live up to our expectations.  First of all, I had the "Solomillo de Corzo" which I do not think was from a Roe Deer (corzo). I am a hunter myself and have harvested several corzo and the solomillo's are tiny. This was probably a "Solomillo de Ciervo" from a Spanish red deer judging from the size of the piece of meat. It if was "Solomillo de Corzo" then it was from a giant Roe Deer. In any event, despite the nice sauce and presentation the meat was dry as venison tends to be unless cooked perfectly. This was not the case here. Also, we ordered the alcachofas (artichokes) and were again disappointed. They were nothing special and suffered in comparison with delectable and tasty artichokes I've had at other establishments. We also had the Huevos Rotos for an appetizer and they were good with Pimientos de Padrón (famous Padrón peppers) but again, nothing special.  The wine recommended to us was OK but again just nothing to rave about for 16.90 Euro. The desserts and coffee were also OK. I'm not sure I would spend the money to return to L'abbracio unless it was some matter of convenience and I needed to go to a restaurant nearby to my home. We spent 86 Euro for 2 persons and this reflected a 20% discount from El Tenedor.

title_review: Lovely Place to enjoy a meal
review_preview: I found this restaurant through trip advisor and was very please we went here for our first dinner in Madrid. It was very close to our hotel as well which made things easier. Although we arrived at 8:30 p.m. the place was really empty as...
review_full: I found this restaurant through trip advisor and was very please we went here for our first dinner in Madrid. It was very close to our hotel as well which made things easier. Although we arrived at 8:30 p.m. the place was really empty as the Spanish people tend to eat very late compared to Canadians. My wife had the crispy leg of lamb which was very overcooked and really seemed to be deep fried? To bad as the reviews were very good on this item. I had a Carpaccio of sea bass and prawn which was amazing. It was so good my wife shared it with me. I had stuffed ravioli as a main that was also very tasty.  We enjoyed a very nice bottle of wine and the owners also gave us a free liquor after our meal. we considered the price reasonable at 89 Euros. I asked a server if the total included a tip and she assured me it did so we left thinking this was what was done in Spain, however not long afterward I read online that what I thought was the tip was in fact the VAT/ I returned the next day and in very broken Spanish apologized to the owner and left an appropriate tip for the server. The owner was most gracious and seemed pleasantly surprised we came back. I would not hesitate to return to eat here again!

Of course everything was topped off with some smooth Spanish vino tinto. I can,t seem to remember my dessert but I am sure it was consistent with the entire meal. I should also mention the decor was very inviting. When visiting Madrid make time to have dinner at the Fuente De La Fama. 3 of us went back a 2nd time!

review_preview: If you want to have the best milk fed baby lamb roasted the way they have been doing it for eons in many Segovia villages this is the place. Put several hours of your agenda on  this visit rather than driving.  It is amazing that...
review_full: If you want to have the best milk fed baby lamb roasted the way they have been doing it for eons in many Segovia villages this is the place. Put several hours of your agenda on this visit rather than driving. It is amazing that an authentic adobe oven fed with Spanish oak wood functions in the middle of the city. It is all authentic. The interior is not modern chick, more like you find in a rustic restaurant in the Segovia province. You want true heart of Spain feel here you find it. Even the customers are mostly Spanish and connoiseurs of good lamb. Just like in those restaurants the menu is not a smorgasbor of items. Here you come for the roast, and their lamb is the best . It may be equaled but nor surpassed. The meat is tender, moist and juicy. It is accompanied by a lettuce and tomato salad. In our case for starters we took their blood pudding (morcilla) and croquetes as well as some La Granja beans and it was satiating. The great meat portions are perhaps excessive for standard American habits, specially for lunch but come in with after a very light breakfast and be prepared to skip dinner. Very few people we know could cope with the full meal and need further sustenance the rest of the day. The house wine is just right for this type of dinner and the homemade bread and white tablecloths retain that homey feeling. The service was extremely efficient even though they had a full house.  The restaurant is not in a fashionable, yet safe, neighborhood and the hotel across the street provides parking. For the visitor it would be easier to take a taxi or, cheaper and faster yet, the subway with a station two blocks away . It is fantastic to experience real Spanish roast, at reasonable prices and because it has received an extremely favorable report from Madrid TV a reservation is necessary.  My rating is relative to other grill houses or asadores anywhere. This a problem with tripadvisor where there are no categories and an absolute scale does not exist. Yet, if you want a super tasty meal and you are a roasted lamb lover the ranking applies. No frills, molecular cuisine or modern colorful presentations, just plain good food from down the farm in a feast day.

title_review: Tortillas are amazing, beer is very expensive though!
review_preview: I love a good tortilla and have eaten here a few times and I've yet to have a bad one but the brie one (which they serve ever day) is just amazing.If the review was based on just the tortilla is would get 5...
review_full: I love a good tortilla and have eaten here a few times and I've yet to have a bad one but the brie one (which they serve ever day) is just amazing. If the review was based on just the tortilla is would get 5 stars. But in a city where a pint of beer is usally 2-3 euros, charging €7 is just mental. Not to mention where everywhere else, when serving a pint, serves a European pint (568 ml), this place serves 'American pints', which are actually 20% smaller, a fact that I don't think most people realise. So both combined makes for a very expensive pint. So for that 1 star is removed. Not to mention a spirit and mixer will set you back around €13, so spirits are ridiculously expensive too. On the weekends this place is absolutely rammed, so you'll usually have to stand. I'm taking another star off because during the week, when it isn't that buzy, they don't have enough chairs to match the number of tables; so you have people needlessly standing up, very often seeing one table with one poor bloke standing whilst the rest are seated.  The takeaway ordering is very quick though and it's great that you can pre-order a whole tortilla to take away with you. One note I would make is that whilst it opens at 1800, it doesn't start serving food till 1900.

review_preview: My wife and I arrived this morning in Madrid t o begin a three week vacation in Spain and Portugal. After arriving at our hotel and taking a short rest, we went out to explore. My wife chose this restaurant and WOW!When we first...
review_full: My wife and I arrived this morning in Madrid t o begin a three week vacation in Spain and Portugal. After arriving at our hotel and taking a short rest, we went out to explore. My wife chose this restaurant and WOW! When we first went in around 2:15pm, there was only one other table occupied, but by the time we left around 4:00PM, there were no empty spots. The service is prompt, efficient and extremely courteous. Juan Manuel was our principal interface. We both ordered seafood. One the Hake with garlic confit, the other cod and scallops. Living on the Gulf of Mexico, we are used to great seafood. These two dishes blew us away! Both were so well prepared, the fish melted in your mouth. We also enjoyed a lentil soup, mixed salad for two and a special treat do chocolate truffles that rival anything Robert Linx prepares at Madison du Chocolat in Paris.  Moderately priced and worth every cent! Highly recommended!!

title_review: Incredibly Quality and Service!  A Real Find!
review_preview: I extensively research top Basque restaurants and wanted one that served Cogote de Merluza (my favorite dish). This trip I tried three new places and this one was the best, though others more well know. This one was incredible! This is a best kept secret...
review_full: I extensively research top Basque restaurants and wanted one that served Cogote de Merluza (my favorite dish). This trip I tried three new places and this one was the best, though others more well know. This one was incredible! This is a best kept secret for sure. Everything we ordered was stellar in both superb presentation, quality, taste and elegant astute service. My companion had the Leg of lamb which was gorgeous to see - though I did not eat - but he who did found it exquisite! The atmosphere was extremely pleasant and the staff so kind and warm - not stuffy but genuinely thoughtful and ready to meet any need. I cannot recommend enough! And price was the best value for what you are getting.

review_preview: While searching for a place that serves excellent cochinello asado, in Segovia style, happened to come across this wonderful place, and have no regrets!  Took the risk of also inviting two food loving friends who have lived in Madrid for over 8 years, and had...
review_full: While searching for a place that serves excellent cochinello asado, in Segovia style, happened to come across this wonderful place, and have no regrets! Took the risk of also inviting two food loving friends who have lived in Madrid for over 8 years, and had never heard of it. A superb meal, with ambience and the attention of a well trained and experienced staff. We were able to put ourselves in the hands of a knowledgeable maitre de, who guided us with additional selections (wagyu rabo, lamb in Segovia style, and a superb hake) and a wine to accompany the meal. Our starter dish was the signal of things to come, a mixed plate of cheese from Pamplona and top quality jamon iberico de bellota...a sign of the attention to quality...and indeed that was clear for everything that followed. Chef Juan Carlos Pena, combines this regional classicism with a modern touch and (such as the tempura vegetables that accompany the Wagyu Oxtail) This is a culinary gem that deserves attention and appreciation of those who enjoy excellent gastronomic experience. First rate and memorable, do not miss this !

But the interior of the tortillas was runny and that ruined it for me, unfortunately.

title_review: Possibly The Best Tortilla In Town
review_preview: Pez Tortilla is were I ate the best tortilla of my life!We were told about Pez Tortilla but a friend who lived in Madrid ... and she wasn’t wrong. The place is a small gem, populated by locals, which is a good sign! They...
review_full: Pez Tortilla is were I ate the best tortilla of my life! We were told about Pez Tortilla but a friend who lived in Madrid ... and she wasn’t wrong. The place is a small gem, populated by locals, which is a good sign!  They have 10 craft beers on tap, plenty of tortilla flavours to choose from and an incredible assortment of freshly fried croquetas.  The place is cheap, the tortilla is incredibly tasty and creamy, the croquetas are super crisp outside and melting inside, although they are freshly fried so ... they are also hotter than the sun! Highly recommended for dinner and a beer. Be aware the place is small. So you have to queue for space!

title_review: Amazing staff that helped us feel safe
review_preview: Went there with my friend (we are both tourists) and sat at a table enjoying our night. We had 1 drink here and an hour later a man sat at a stool beside us and began talking to us and asking questions, making us uncomfortable....
review_full: Went there with my friend (we are both tourists) and sat at a table enjoying our night. We had 1 drink here and an hour later a man sat at a stool beside us and began talking to us and asking questions, making us uncomfortable. A lady who is part of the staff immediately made eye contact with my friend and asked if we are okay with her thumb. My friend nodded no and she came to our rescue by asking the man to stop interjecting our conversation and night. We headed out a couple minutes after that and while we were leaving, another staff member came and apologized to us for the situation. We stood out for our Uber and the creepy man came out the door to talk to us again. As soon as he said a couple things, a 3rd staff member opened the door and waited with us till we got safely in our Uber. We were so touched by how nice and caring they were and recommend this place to everyone!!!

title_review: Tortilla the way it should be (Spanish omelette)
review_preview: If you're not familiar with tortilla de patata, it's a Spanish breakfast, lunch, or dinner staple: a French omelette but heartier as it's made with passion and potatoes (onions are a contentious ingredient). Most Spanish people will tell you their granny's tortilla is best. But...
review_full: If you're not familiar with tortilla de patata, it's a Spanish breakfast, lunch, or dinner staple: a French omelette but heartier as it's made with passion and potatoes (onions are a contentious ingredient). Most Spanish people will tell you their granny's tortilla is best. But I suppose that's because they haven't happened upon Pez Tortilla on Calle Pez in the heart of hipster Malasaña. And it's unlikely she adds brie and truffle to hers (my personal favourite).  Here there is a wide variety of different fillings - or you can have the traditional basic tortilla. They're served gooey with many morsels of bread to soak up the delights. Helpfully, there are also several different beers to sample alongside your culinary exquisite take on peasant food and the hustle and bustle busy environment adds to the authentic Spanish vibe. It's loud with chatter and you're lucky to find a perch, but that all doesn't really matter as the food and the ambience does the trick.

review_preview: I was recommended by a colleague to head to the Justicia District - which is the area north of Calle Gran Via. It is very much a locals area, which is very vibrant and packed with restaurants and bars. Given the virtually unlimited choice, I...
review_full: I was recommended by a colleague to head to the Justicia District - which is the area north of Calle Gran Via. It is very much a locals area, which is very vibrant and packed with restaurants and bars.  Given the virtually unlimited choice, I asked Trip Advisor which suggested Pez - which looked right up my alley. A few blocks walk and I was there - as were a lot of people. It was jam packed - it's not very big! Positioning myself near the bar, it took about 10 minutes to be served - selecting one of their ales of the day and two croquettes. I couldn't translate the varieties, so the bar attendant selected cheese for me. The beer and croquettes were a great combination - for €5! Given Pez prides itself on tortilla - I had to sample one and went for the first one on the menu - I could read ham and cheese, so that sounded good enough. The tortilla is a large slice, served with two slices of bread. It was delicious - also combined with another IPA selection to wash it down! Muchos gracias Pez for feeding a solo traveller. Note - it is full of twenty-somethings that all spoke Spanish, so very much a locals scene. Do yourself a favour and head to Pez when in Madrid.

The place is small so go with time in order to find a table (and chair!)

review_preview: This is a cool little restaurant in the center of Madrid with a unique concept...they only serve one entree: a boneless ribeye steak with a special sauce they have imported from the original Cafe de Paris in Geneva.  The butter-based sauce is incredible, different than...
review_full: This is a cool little restaurant in the center of Madrid with a unique concept...they only serve one entree: a boneless ribeye steak with a special sauce they have imported from the original Cafe de Paris in Geneva. The butter-based sauce is incredible, different than anything else I've tried. For a very reasonable price, you get a salad, steak and all the fries you want. They've got a small, but well thought out wine list and we liked the desserts.  It's a bright, clean restaurant that's as good for a date as it is for a group of friends. You don't see a lot of places like that in Madrid. Highly recommended.

Good range of desserts too. I try to have a meal here every time I visit Madrid. It's truly a hidden gem in an area full of famous restaurants, some of which are not actually that great (despite the overwhelming number of pictures of supposedly famous people hanging on their walls...what's that all about?)

title_review: You should know what to expect
review_preview: You don't get a choice, the menu is set and quite clear (just like it is in all the Entrecôte restaurants in Europe or elsewhere), that is a salad, a steak in a very rich sauce, and lots of french fries. Oh and the bill...
review_full: You don't get a choice, the menu is set and quite clear (just like it is in all the Entrecôte restaurants in Europe or elsewhere), that is a salad, a steak in a very rich sauce, and lots of french fries. Oh and the bill is quite high, but that too you should know because the price doesn't vary that much from one place to another. Now, I have been in several Entrecôte restaurants, and this one had its pleasant surprises and its disappointments. The salad was disappointing, the vinaigrette was too strong and well, there was no "noix"... The meat was delicious and tender and melted in your mouth, it was excellent. The sauce however was good but not amazingly so, it was too heavy, it was flooded with butter, just too much of it. The french fries were delicious, and quite addictive! Now, comes the bill,if you add desert, wine and water, coffee or tea, then the whole experience starts to feel sour and you might have trouble digesting your food... It was good, but I had better.

review_preview: If you have tried, L’Entrecote de Paris in Paris, then you need to try L’Entrecote Cafe de Paris (in Madrid). L’Entrecote Cafe de Paris will not disappoint and in my opinion is superior to L’Entrecote de Paris in Paris. Frequently believed to be associated to...
review_full: If you have tried, L’Entrecote de Paris in Paris, then you need to try L’Entrecote Cafe de Paris (in Madrid). L’Entrecote Cafe de Paris will not disappoint and in my opinion is superior to L’Entrecote de Paris in Paris. Frequently believed to be associated to L’Entrecote de Paris in Paris, L’Entrecote Cafe de Paris (Madrid) is not. L’Entrecote Cafe de Paris is part of a small network of international restaurants, the first one starting in Geneva, Switzerland. All these restaurants have the same menu and sauce, but are independently owned. We were greeted by the owner, who explained that “many try to imitate the sauce” used in L’Entrecote Cafe de Paris, but none can replicate it. The sauce is made by one person for all the restaurants. L’Entrecote Cafe de Paris only serves steak with a special secret sauce (which is absolutely delicious and the reason you should visit). There are two sides: french fries and salad . There are a variety of desserts and are all made in house (I had Spanish Torrijas and found them to be yummy). I had a glass of wine made in Madrid (also recommended by owner) and was not disappointed. I highly recommend L’Entrecote Cafe de Paris and believe you won’t regret it.

review_preview: We arrived as a party of 6 and were seated fairly quickly. We had to attract the attention of a waiter to take our drinks order bearing in mind that the restaurant was not particularly busy at the time of our booking. Drinks having arrived,...
review_full: We arrived as a party of 6 and were seated fairly quickly. We had to attract the attention of a waiter to take our drinks order bearing in mind that the restaurant was not particularly busy at the time of our booking. Drinks having arrived, we were pretty much ignored until we were able to catch the eye of a waitress who was brilliant in every way i.e. efficient friendly and attentive. I have to say that she pretty much was doing the job of two people. The waiter who was on a slow and stop mission managed to lock himself out of the restaurant much to our amusement but not that of the person in charge of the restaurant. There were a lot of home deliveries flying out the door and also people coming by to collect their take-out orders. We were served our salad which was pretty much what you would expect a salad to be followed by our steak which was individually cooked to our liking and which was very good indeed covered by the 'special' sauce. The fries on the first round were not particularly hot but the ones brought out for the second service were and you were allowed as much as you wanted. All in all a pleasant evening and the final bill amounted to 205 euros. For this we had 6 steak meals, 4 beers, a bottle of wine, 2 bottles of water and a coffee.

title_review: Locals and visitors have different expectations
review_preview: ‘8 oz of local steak’ says the description of the dish, both on the menu and on the colorful photo outside. That less than half of that is edible became clear as I stabbed around trying to find the (tasty) meat amidst the fat.The...
review_full: ‘8 oz of local steak’ says the description of the dish, both on the menu and on the colorful photo outside. That less than half of that is edible became clear as I stabbed around trying to find the (tasty) meat amidst the fat. The suckling pig dish was mostly white gelatinous fat, with a thin strip of (tasty) meat, swimming in a soup of grease.  The padrón peppers at the side of the dishes proved to be a mix of mild and superhot: padrón peppers can be mild (2/3 of them) or extremely hot. Tourists should know that eating a mild one is no guarantee that the next one will be mild too: taking a tiny test bite of each is imperative unless you want to risk losing your taste buds for the rest of your meal.  When we complained, the restaurant manager, the only one who spoke some English, was responsive, but not apologetic: that is how it is, the traditional local steak has a lot of fat, and so does the suckling pig. And Spaniards like the suspense of ‘what’s this padrón going to be like?’ Fuenta la Fama caters to locals as well as to tourists. As we entered a middle-aged Spanish couple was being greeted by the Maître D’ they clearly knew. But the room we were seated in was mostly filled with tourists, including a group of more than 20 English high school students and their teachers. It may well be difficult to please both groups. As we were in the tourist category, we would have liked a waiter who speaks at least some English and is able to educate us, particularly about the padrón roulette.

review_preview: Very straight forward uncomplicated food, well prepared in a traditional establishment, with wood burning oven in the back of the front room ( I think there is additional seating downstairs, but didn't explore.  Grilled red peppers and grilled asparagus were good starters, and left us...
review_full: Very straight forward uncomplicated food, well prepared in a traditional establishment, with wood burning oven in the back of the front room ( I think there is additional seating downstairs, but didn't explore.  Grilled red peppers and grilled asparagus were good starters, and left us hungry enough to greatly enjoy the exceptional quarter lamb for two (40€); very young lamb slow roasted to fork tenderness then finished in a hot oven to crisp the skin, served family style. No additional seasoning needed, except for the garlic slivers tucked here and there in the decent sized portion of lamb. Rice pudding was typical of the region, a bit runny and with more cinnamon than we like, and dairy/egg style tart unremarkable but good. Service was no-frills, professional and deft. For some reason, there was a 10% discount for dinner on the Wednesday night in May we dined. Total before discount was 94€ for two starters, the lamb, two deserts, two coffees, and a very good Ribera del Duero ( a bit pricey at 25€) NB: Restaurant closed Monday nights

review_preview: This restaurant on Calle Atocha was recommended to us as it was within walking distance of our great hotel, "Catalonia Las Cortes", so we arranged a booking for Saturday night. Being used to eating somewhat earlier than seems popular locally, we made the mistake of...
review_full: This restaurant on Calle Atocha was recommended to us as it was within walking distance of our great hotel, "Catalonia Las Cortes", so we arranged a booking for Saturday night. Being used to eating somewhat earlier than seems popular locally, we made the mistake of reserving our table for 8.30 p.m. - probably an hour earlier than we should have done. Anyway, the restaurant looks fine from outside, and helpfully displays a multi-lingual Menu. Inside is quite "traditional", with space for about 60 people - one wall in the rectangular layout is all mirrors, which is a little disconcerting initially. We got a reasonable welcome, and were allowed select a table - a good start to the evening. English language skills are not one of the strengths here, but we got through the ordering process with a mixture of our "poquito" of Espanol and our Waiter's smidgen of English! We decided to share a plate of Iberian Ham as a Starter, my "Better Half", M. selected Roast Suckling Pig for a Main, and I opted for the Escallop of Veal. We also ordered a bottle of "Albarino" to accompany our meal. As is customary in several restaurants we visited, we were served what I call a "pre-starter" - I can't say what was in this sausage-like concoction (and language limitations prevented a description by staff), but whatever it was, it proved quite tasty. Our wine was delivered - no displaying of the Bottle or offer of a taste before it was poured into our glasses - and it was satisfactory. The "Iberian Ham" was what it said it was, without being distinctive as regards texture or flavour. M's "Roast Suckling Pig" was reasonable too - it probably wasn't the wisest choice on her part, as she doesn't like fat, but she acknowledged that the meat at the core was "good". My "Escallop of Veal" was excellent - served in the Milanese style (in light batter), it was cooked appropriately, and was all the more tasty when I requested a slice of Lemon as an accompaniment. We noted, by the way, that other customers began to arrive from 9.15 p.m. onwards, and undoubtedly their presence improved the atmosphere in the restaurant. Our Bill (before gratuity) came to Euro 79-40, and we departed fairly satisfied - our basic comments on "Fuente de la Fama" are that their offering is safe & traditional (with meat the best option), portion sizes are good, service is courteous, and prices are reasonable.

title_review: Where good carnivores go when they die...
review_preview: Frankly I don't understand some of the poor reviews on here... for €35 per head (for the fixed price menu) you get:# Starter of cold roast peppers, decent (not outstanding) chorizo and the best black pudding / morcilla in the history of the universe....
review_full: Frankly I don't understand some of the poor reviews on here... for €35 per head (for the fixed price menu) you get: # Starter of cold roast peppers, decent (not outstanding) chorizo and the best black pudding / morcilla in the history of the universe. Frankly I'd pay €20 for the morcilla alone. You also get a very generous helping of fresh baked foccacia-style bread. ***ALERT*** don't overdo it on the bread - you'll need the room. # Main course of either suckling pig or milk-fed lamb. The menu actually specifies the lamb but in practice they let you have either so a couple can share both. The meat is cooked in a wood burning oven on an earthenware dish and is seasoned just with salt and lemon juice. The sauce is simply the cooking juices let down with a little water - they should serve it in wine glasses... The lamb is delicately flavoured as milk-fed lamb tends to be but succulent and beautiful. The pork is simply sublime - full flavoured, wonderful crackling - the latter even included the little curly tail. The meat is served with a simple lettuce/tomato/onion salad (a huge bowl full) with a nice, simple dressing. # Desert is quoted as being the local special (effectively a mille feuille) but the waiter said we could have whatever desert we wanted from the menu. We stuck with the special which was ok, nothing more, but frankly we were stuffed anyway. # A bottle of decent rebeira (between 2) # A local liqueur with little hard sweet pastry balls to soak in it. # Coffee # Very friendly and attentive service from someone who wanted to make sure we had a great time despite neither of us speaking any Spanish beyond 'hola' 'dos cerveza' and 'vino tinto'. If that isn't worth a bit under £30 per head then I don't know what is. ...just don't take a veggie with you.

title_review: the lamb maybe dead but tis not to die for!!!
review_preview: Twas a wet n windy night in madrid, beckoning thru the dark dank mist shone the lights of  - Asador Aranda (Plaza Castillas). Having had to forgo our planned and much anticipated return to the tapas bars of central madrid due to the above meteorological...
review_full: Twas a wet n windy night in madrid, beckoning thru the dark dank mist shone the lights of - Asador Aranda (Plaza Castillas). Having had to forgo our planned and much anticipated return to the tapas bars of central madrid due to the above meteorological conditons we entered this bastion of spanish chain cuisine with some trepidation........ok enough waxing lyrecisms (is that really a word?). Review - choose from lamb or entrecote (or suckling pig on wednesdays and fridays but don,t expect any on a early friday evening (early for madrid that is) as this bustling restaurant with one other table had sold out!!! Starter a shared revuelto with setas and jamon iberico was ok but finding any jamon was...well needles in a haystack springs to mind...and at 12 euros for flavoured scramble eggs... it should be ok! The roast lamb, their thing, ok but when thats all you cook (besides a plain steak) it should be good and roasting a small joint in a wood oven till it falls off the bone is not really rocket science! The chulletas or i should say chulletitas (thats small, very small lamb cutlets) are served in their own dish on top of smoking coals, bit gimmiky but ok if you like that sort of thing. However as they are cut only slightly thicker than an ice cream wafer (if that) theres no worry of finding any blushing pink succulent meat as they are cooked and the towel thrown in as soon as they come in sight of a grill ! The entrecote, well yes a nice piece of meat with a pinch of salt as its adornement and garnished with two pieces of red pepper and half a grilled tomato again not really challenging when thats all you offer your customers! The cutlets by the way were accompanied by.......... a nice white plate to which you could transfer them but forget the knife or fork as the only way to locate and remove what meat there is, is by hand! Add on: a salad served in a bowl reminiscent of what i user to eat my cornflakes out of and consisting of lettuce, tomato AND topped with some raw onion at 6.50 a time, a bottle of very average house red and two cafe solos - with a bill topping over nearly 70 euros you have to ask yourself does this represent value for money and would you go back...... the answer.......well you decide!  (ps. my girlfriend and i, hate the word partner, have lived in Spain since..........well Franco was still very much alive and kicking........ so think we know a thing or two about spanish cuisine and restaurants... just in case you was wondering!!!)

I asked for olive oil for my bread, but the waitress didn't bother and I didn't feel like pursuing it.  If you like lamb and that peculiar european busy restaurant scene, then this is the place for you. I didn't like the service but I'll be back for the lamb.

We managed to get the last table although you could certainly stand at the bar. The waitress explained the options to us and we chose a 2 types of tortilla and some vegetable curry croquettes. What can I say? Everything was absolutely delicious. The tortilla was like nothing I had ever tasted, the texture and flavour was just amazing. I had truffled Brie and my friend the mushroom and as they were so good we then shared a mixed pepper one and had more croquettes. We saw someone ordering a full tortilla to share (18 euros) or 3 euros for a generous portion. A wonderful selection of beers too. I could have stayed all night. It just goes to show - offer a limited choice and do it extremely well and you will be successful. You MUST go.

This little bar was hopping when we arrived around 10pm. There was no room but quickly opened up. Most every dish was sold out, so be sure to get there early if you have your heart set on a specific tortilla. The tortillas too, I might add aren't the tortillas we are thinking of, if you are from California. Their dishes were more like a frittata. An egg batter mix with filling inside. We had the caramelized onions--it really was delicious. It also had potatoes inside too. We also ordered pisto croquettes that were wonderful. It was really busy and loud at this little gem, but a nice treat and something different than the other bars in Madrid.

review_full: I ate lunch at Fuente de la Fama on Tuesday, December 14, 2015 and I highly recommend it. I had the set menu which had several choices for each of the three courses. I had the Lentils Castellena, the fish in green sauce and a heavenly slice of a type of cheese cake with caramel. The cost was 12.50 Euros total as the IVA tax was included and it also came with bread and wine. It's about a 20 minute walk from Sol or just steps from the Anton Martin metro station. title_review: Very good food marred by a rip-off
review_preview: Three of us (two French, one British) travelling on business were attracted by the Eur12.50 set menu for a simple lunch.  First off, we were only given the a la carte menu, and had to request the set menu which arrived slightly grudgingly.  Then, when...
review_full: Three of us (two French, one British) travelling on business were attracted by the Eur12.50 set menu for a simple lunch. First off, we were only given the a la carte menu, and had to request the set menu which arrived slightly grudgingly. Then, when clearly choosing from the set menu, the waiter said that there was a special of the day, roast lamb, for 2 or 3. We chose to have that, for three, initially assuming that it was a smallish portion as part of the set menu. However, when a huge plate of lamb arrived, suspicions were aroused that we had been covertly "sold up". The bill confirmed this: the lamb was charged in two items at 18 and 47 Euros, against a 3 Euro per head reduction in the set menu price. Querying this, we were told that this was 47 for the two portions and 18 for the single portion, and that he had asked us if we wanted 2 or 3 portions. Setting aside the extremely peculiar arithmetic between the two figures, it's sad that restaurants and waiters feel that this sort of thing is fair game with foreigners, and it marred an otherwise excellent meal. By all means go here: the food is really nice, it's a pleasant place and the service is friendly. But be thoroughly on your guard.

And he was right. The informal and friendly attention we received has added much to the impressions of the excellent food we had. Highly recommended.

review_preview: My wife and I visited the restaurant a couple nights ago whilst on a quick trip to Madrid. We arrived early enough to get a free table as we hadn't made a reservation. We were met by the unfriendly host and seated at a small...
review_full: My wife and I visited the restaurant a couple nights ago whilst on a quick trip to Madrid. We arrived early enough to get a free table as we hadn't made a reservation. We were met by the unfriendly host and seated at a small table. He didn't offer to take our coats as he did with every other table he seated. We were given the menus and received no advise or explanations.  The menu is pricy. We ordered for starters a plat of Iberico ham which was expensive but excellent, as well as a plate of peppers. These were straight out of a jar and cost €5!  For mains we ordered lamb chops and received just that, 5 chops each on a mini grill on the table. The waiter, knowing we are tourists and probably first timers, never asked if we would like to order some potatoes or salad with the meat as it doesn't come with anything. And we ordered a bottle of Pesquera for nearly €30 and it tasted like it was kept in the oven all summer. So stick to house wine if you do decide to go. I have to say the lamb chops were some of the tastiest and tender I've ever had. All and all, it was hard to still enjoy the meal with my wife and not get annoyed.

title_review: A bit of heaven during difficult times
review_preview: We had to come to Madrid on an emergency trip to acquire a temporary passport.  Mine was lost/stolen 10 minutes after arriving in Sevilla.  We went to the Asador because it was literally around the corner from the Meliá Galgos hotel, closest accommodations  to the...
review_full: We had to come to Madrid on an emergency trip to acquire a temporary passport. Mine was lost/stolen 10 minutes after arriving in Sevilla. We went to the Asador because it was literally around the corner from the Meliá Galgos hotel, closest accommodations to the Embassy. The space was welcoming, warm, decorated in what I would call España-iana. We both had the prix fixe. The appetizers were a superb selection of charcuterie, including wonderful blood sausages, hard to find in the US. I mentioned to our server that I was not fond of lamb, and there was a prompt substitution for suckling pig, as good if not better than the famed dish from Segovia. Heavenly. The service was attentive, friendly and professional. In the middle of the angst created by the nature of the trip, this restaurant was a wonderful comforting experience.

review_full: Has two different beers they had on barrel. The Dougall's Raquera and the Leyenda. Both were really good. The croquetas: I ordered a jamon iberico and curry de pollo, the ham one was great but the curry de pollo was a very interesting flavor as I had never tried curry in a croqueta. Both were good stuff, just wait a little for them to get warm because they're served hot since they're made in the moment. That's somehting I really like which is the ingredients they use are all natural and homemade. As a con, they take longer time to make.  I arrived at the place around 8:00PM which I recommend if you want to find a spot. At exactly 8:30 PM the place starts to get crowded and the staff gets overburdened at times. I recommend it if you want to have a nice beer and great tapas at reasonable prices.

review_preview: This was one of several bars and restaurants on Pez street, all of which were happy and buzzing by 9pm.  Small place, nice ambiance for a warm, happy group of young people all chatting away and enjoying several types of draft beer.  Seating is limited....
review_full: This was one of several bars and restaurants on Pez street, all of which were happy and buzzing by 9pm. Small place, nice ambiance for a warm, happy group of young people all chatting away and enjoying several types of draft beer. Seating is limited. We ordered beer, tortilla (they offer half a dozen flavours), and two types of croquetas. The beer and slice of omelette is ready immediately and quite tasty. The bill was wrong at first as the bartender charged us for a racion (7€) when we only ordered a duo (2€). No biggie. But 25 minutes later, still no croquetas and stretching toward 10pm. Their tiny kitchen was overtaxed? As the menu only included two types of food and no other tapas, this place is really only suitable for appetizers before dinner, and no way to stretch four or five appetizers into a light dinner. Eventually we left (having never received our croquetas but for 4€ not a great loss) and went to another restaurant for a more substantial meal. If you are looking at this listing and like did, we recommend you seek out Lateral instead, just a few blocks east.

title_review: Nice atmosphere, good service and food
review_preview: We had a late lunch (14.45) and there was plenty of room. One of us ordered cod with scallops but after a while we were told that the scallops had run out so he switched to hake, which was very good. Two of us shared...
review_full: We had a late lunch (14.45) and there was plenty of room. One of us ordered cod with scallops but after a while we were told that the scallops had run out so he switched to hake, which was very good. Two of us shared a seafood paella, which was good but not outstanding - possibly a little too salty and not quite up to Valencia standards. Service was good, even though we had no Spanish and the waiter's English was modest. However, he declined to serve wine by the glass, which meant that we had none. That surely is not good practice - at least the restaurant should offer house wine by the glass. Deserts were splendid. A nice atmosphere and altogether it is recommendable.

review_preview: Positives- the food. top notch, typical dishes are cordero (lamb) and cochinillo (pork) which are cooked in a stone oven if i remember correctly.   the starters are also great and even the salad has very fresh ingredients. these are one of the most delicious...
review_full: Positives - the food. top notch, typical dishes are cordero (lamb) and cochinillo (pork) which are cooked in a stone oven if i remember correctly. the starters are also great and even the salad has very fresh ingredients. these are one of the most delicious dishes we have in spain and after living 25 years in Madrid think this is the best place to eat them. now live in london and every once in a while when i'm back this is the first place i pick to go with family or friends. - the decoration/space inside. nothing too fashionable but transmits a warm, cosy feeling with its wooden colour and also allows for enough space between tables.  - the service. it's led by the daughter of the owner and cook (cristobal). she personally takes care of every table and is very helpful. she is polite, charismatic and professional. - although not very cheap, eating food of this quality for this price is not easy to find. should expect to pay 35-40 per head with wine Negatives - one of the few reviews i don't have much to say here. you get what you pay for and even more. perhaps the street it is in could be a bit nicer? other - they have an agreement with a hotel right in the opposite side of the street where you can park your car for free for the first two hours. no need to pay "parquimetro" - if you are a large group best to tell them in advance if you are eating cordero or cochinillo

review_preview: We flew in to Madrid for the day as we were treating my parents, who are celebrating their 50th wedding anniversary this year. We booked in advance as we wanted to be sure of getting a table. All the reviews had said that this was...
review_full: We flew in to Madrid for the day as we were treating my parents, who are celebrating their 50th wedding anniversary this year. We booked in advance as we wanted to be sure of getting a table. All the reviews had said that this was a good restaurant. The reviews were right! The food was excellent, the service was very efficient and the price was incredible. We all had the set menu (three courses with lots of choice), plus a bottle of wine and a bottle of cava, all of which came to less than €100! The restaurant was very busy, always a good sign, with a wide range of people from families to business meetings. Well worth a visit and we will definitely go again - all we need is a good excuse to do another day trip. In fact, another lunch at Mercado de la Reina is all the excuse we need!!

It was perfect with the bread and olives they gave us. Then we had the lamb which was so incredibly succulent and cooked perfectly. Last we ended with the flan with raspberry sauce and it was hands down the best flan I've had in Spain yet. It had great balance of sweet and creamy and paired with the raspberry it was perfection. Service was outstanding. I highly recommend eating here! Gracias por todo!

title_review: The place to devour the perfect baby lamb with outstanding service
review_preview: This place is a must when visiting Madrid if you are looking for the best lamb in a beautiful and centrally located restaurant. I've been coming here for years and all I can say is that it gets better. We were celebrating a friend's birthday...
review_full: This place is a must when visiting Madrid if you are looking for the best lamb in a beautiful and centrally located restaurant. I've been coming here for years and all I can say is that it gets better. We were celebrating a friend's birthday and the staff serving our table couldn't have been more attentive and professional. A total of 6 waiters rotated to serve our entrees and to collect the dishes, as we devoured them. The menu of the day included roasted peppers, blood sausages, chorizos coupled with a cup of lamb broth, which was outstanding .The lamb was served with a tossed salad, followed by two outstanding and large desserts: cheese flan with raspberries and a cake with milhojas. A bottle of an incredible red wine was also part of the deal, followed by a herbal liqueur with rosquillas de anís. Total for two was $75 Euros. A steal for what you get . I highly, highly recommend this place that keeps getting better through the years.

review_preview: My wife and I had a most wonderful dinner at Asador de Aranda. We arrived early for dinner and were seated promptly. We ordered the fixed menu for both an appetizer of blood sausage, chorizo and roasted red peppers (delicious) a leg or shoulder quarter...
review_full: My wife and I had a most wonderful dinner at Asador de Aranda. We arrived early for dinner and were seated promptly. We ordered the fixed menu for both an appetizer of blood sausage, chorizo and roasted red peppers (delicious) a leg or shoulder quarter of roasted milk fed young lamb, which was roasted on the premises in a wood fired oven (outstanding) accompanied by a large lettuce, tomatoes and sweet onions salad with a delicious vinagrete dressing. This meal also included a delicious bottle of Ribera del Duero red wine, and after all that, desert a complimentary after dinner drink and coffee. All this for 37.50 euro each. We highly recommend Asador de Aranda as a very special place to have a very special meal.

title_review: Great and Fun Experience for Welcoming the New Year
review_preview: Our two families made reservations for the Mercado de la Reina New Year's or Noche Vieja Extravaganza. There were locals, tourists and ex pats. Lots of food for a fixe price plus all the wine and cava you can drink, plus all of the NYE...
review_full: Our two families made reservations for the Mercado de la Reina New Year's or Noche Vieja Extravaganza. There were locals, tourists and ex pats. Lots of food for a fixe price plus all the wine and cava you can drink, plus all of the NYE party favors and joking around. Best of all was the traditional eating of the 12 grapes prior to 12am to welcome the New Year and obligatory toasts, like "Saldremos de la Crisis"! To top it off the fixe price included one free drink, i.e. fabulous gin and tonics at the Gin Club downstairs, dancing and listening to 80's,90's and 00's pop music.

review_preview: I booked this restaurant on the advice of a magazine article and when I arrived I thought I'd made a bit of a mistake, as it looks quite 70's and old-fashioned so I wasn't expecting much.  I was wrong!  The food here was excellent -...
review_full: I booked this restaurant on the advice of a magazine article and when I arrived I thought I'd made a bit of a mistake, as it looks quite 70's and old-fashioned so I wasn't expecting much. I was wrong! The food here was excellent - not exactly fine dining, but just really good food. We opted for the set menu which included a croquette, gazpacho, octopus, steak and dessert with wine and it was incredible value. The octopus was really the star of the show - it was beautiful. I was a little disappointed to see the steak was served with chips, but actually it was delicious! I would absolutely recommend this place.

review_preview: This Bistro type restaurant that also offers full white cloth dinning, is in the heart of the city, and very quickly became my wife's and I favorite bistro.It has sidewalk tables as well as bar type stools and a full dinning room. We enjoyed...
review_full: This Bistro type restaurant that also offers full white cloth dinning, is in the heart of the city, and very quickly became my wife's and I favorite bistro. It has sidewalk tables as well as bar type stools and a full dinning room. We enjoyed sitting at the counter where you can see the many variety of tapas displayed in front of you, and also get to enjoy seeing tapas being ordered by others that was not on display. People are interactive, and the service people are amazing in their ability to keep track of the many orders. The variety of food was plentiful, and very reasonably priced. Many of the tapas were priced at 2+ Euros (about $2.70 USD). They were also listed on a very large menu board, as well as smaller hand menus with the many different choices. Both my wife an I enjoy the tasting wine, and that too was offered for about the same price per glass. Needless to say we imbibed repeatedly. The place is narrow at its opening and gets packed with people earlier than most restaurants. It's a great meeting place and a very active social location.  It is located on the Calle Gran Via, which is in the heart of the city and offers many pleasant architectural views.  One of our favorites dishes, which we savored in several different restaurants as well as this one, but always enjoyed, was the Pimentos Padron. They are small Pablano green peppers that are sautéed in oil, and then coated with sea salt. They are served in bunches of about 30-40 pieces and are very reasonably priced. We also enjoyed the many different small Tapas of crisp bread and choices of meats, and vegetables. This is a must stop for a relaxing, casual experience away fro the fine dining that is abundant in Madrid.

review_full: Surprised that this place is not mentioned more in Tripadvisor as the great Tapas restaurant in Madrid it is. Known by all the locals, was always recommended as the place to go in Central Madrid. The tapas selection was amazing; but the most memorable was the Tortilla Pincho. They do this Tortilla different than any other place by adding caramelized onion in the center of the tortilla. It changes the flavor and creates a tortilla that is nothing like you have had before. Great atmosphere and drinks... don't miss this place, and when there, don't miss the tortilla!

review_full: My niece (college age) and I went here at the recommendation of our Rick Steve's guidebook (love him!) as well as our hotel. Had some of our favorite food in Spain at this restaurant...and even went back again for lunch our last day in Madrid after enjoying our dinner so much. We looked around at all the tapas on display but ultimately put ourselves in the hands of the bartender who did not steer us wrong. Everything we had was fantastic - I couldn't pick a favorite! We also loved the summer drinks they were serving which were like a frozen sangria. The atmosphere at the tapas bar was fun with a good crowd and the decor of the bar and restaurant are great...loved the olive tree inside. Highly recommend stopping in!

The pollo asado was perfectly cooked with a wonderful sauce and delicious fries typical of Spain--we weren't that hungry and ate every bit it was so good! Dessert also did not disappoint with fresh strawberries in lemon cream-we could have eaten two or three orders! At 13 Euros we thought this was quite reasonable for this truly delicious meal! We are actually sorry to have to leave Madrid without eating here again!

It was very lively place with a lounge bar with great food vibe.  Was promptly seated at the bar as I was solo and was able to order very quickly.  I was entertained by the bar staff and they made sure everything was good. I had fried cheese balls with jalapenos and then for main the Reina Hamburger.  The burger was very well cooked, tasty and filling.  Only spent 20 euros for the whole meal Sangria, 1 tapas, Gourmet Burger, and an Expresso. Bargain for downtown Madrid! Drop in whether it be just for a snack or a full meal, kitchen open all day!

title_review: A lot of people inside - a good sign of a good restaurant
review_preview: We arrived late night to Madrid and we tried to find a restaurant close to our hotel. It was not so complicated as the neighbourhood is full of cafes and restaurants of all kind (a lot of Japanese-Korean restaurants, by the way). Monday night not...
review_full: We arrived late night to Madrid and we tried to find a restaurant close to our hotel. It was not so complicated as the neighbourhood is full of cafes and restaurants of all kind (a lot of Japanese-Korean restaurants, by the way). Monday night not all of them was welcoming as we agreed to go to a place where we see lot of people: the most important rule for a tourist when he/she is looking for a place where local people go - it means quality, good atmosphere etc. We were not mistaken: first night we tried the upstairs-part of the place, which is a normal "comedor" with seats and tables. The menu is easy to read, also the wine list was clear and not overwhelming- was easy to choose from the range they had. The food is absolutely OK, we were looking for typical spanish meal: asparagus, pimientos del padrón, solomillo, chuletilla, etc...was perfect after a long day, spending hours on a plane.  The next day we came back at lunchtime for tapas and at night, again, but this time sitting only at the big bar-tables, having 2-3 tapas and a "racion" with 2-3 glasses of wine. As Madrid is a capital,prices are higher than in other cities in Spain but still affordable and you get value for your money here. Absolutely satisfied!

review_preview: We had heard a lot about this restaurant, mainly for its great atmosphere as a tapas bar. But we really went for the quiet and cosy restaurant which lies behind the bar (on de la Reina street). The room is much more quieter, has dark...
review_full: We had heard a lot about this restaurant, mainly for its great atmosphere as a tapas bar. But we really went for the quiet and cosy restaurant which lies behind the bar (on de la Reina street). The room is much more quieter, has dark colours but abundant light. The service was very friendly. The dishes were really great. From the starters you MUST try "Salteado de habitas tiernas con jamón Ibérico y huevos del corral" (Sautéed tender green beans with Iberian ham and 2 fried wggs on top) which is so simple in preparation and so astonishing in taste at the same time. For main, I had the "Solomillo de ternera a la plancha con patatas fritas" (tender prime sirloin steak with fried potatoes) which was amazingly tender, juicy and tasty, maybe one of the most delicious stakes I have ever tried. My wife had the "Chuletillas de cordero lechal de Aranda" (lamb cutlets with fried potatoes). I must say that I rarely find lamb cutlets so perfectly grilled (except in my country, Greece :-) ) but these cutlets were absolutely perfectly grilled and very tasty. Keep also in mind that the portions were NOT small, they were very generous and could satisfy every hungry stomach. The prices are reasonable, concerning the great food quality you can find there. Highly recommended !!

review_preview: Himself and I called in here for a bit of lunch whilst tramping about Madrid on a self-walking tour. What we found was a vibrant tapas bar that was trendy, yet laid back. We grabbed a spot on the side near the entrance and ordered...
review_full: Himself and I called in here for a bit of lunch whilst tramping about Madrid on a self-walking tour. What we found was a vibrant tapas bar that was trendy, yet laid back.  We grabbed a spot on the side near the entrance and ordered a few things (Jamón ibérico, green fried asparagus & brie cheese on bread, wild mushrooms with goats cheese on bread, fried jalapeno and cheese croquettes, Gildas (anchovy with olives & green pepper)) and washed it all down with a glass of sangria each. The food we ordered was fantastic (and not too expensive either). Unfortunately we both found that though the free tapa provided with our sangria tasted nice, it had to have been the thickest, creamiest potato salad I've ever seen - so for our health's sake, we pushed that to the side. If we were in the area again, we'd likely pop in again!

title_review: Not ready yet for a Michelin Star
review_preview: My husband and I ate at this restaurant in October, 2018.  The decor is nice and the table settings are interesting.  The wait staff is friendly in person, but they walk about the room stiffly, as if in the army, and they scan the room...
review_full: My husband and I ate at this restaurant in October, 2018. The decor is nice and the table settings are interesting. The wait staff is friendly in person, but they walk about the room stiffly, as if in the army, and they scan the room with such an intent stare that it feels like an army reconnaissance mission. For a more enjoyable evening they should relax a bit. Other fine dining restaurants can do that, so why not this one as well. The food was good but not great. Certainly not for a restaurant aspiring to have a Michelin star (as the brothers who run this restaurant have a two Michelin star restaurant in Barcelona). We shared the cochinillo asado (roast suckling pig) which was good, but certainly not in the class of the cochinillos we have had at other restaurants throughout Spain. The meat was relatively dry with insufficient juices to baste it with. The apple puree that cam with it was too sour. We also shared the cabrito (baby goat meat) which was indeed very good. For a wine we had a nice Pesquera crianza from the Ribera del Duero region. All in all, a potentially fine restaurant, but they have a ways to go to reach Michelin star status, or for that matter, a five star review from me.

review_preview: Talking to the owner at the end of our meal I learnt that this family run place had been in existence for thirty years but this was our first discovery. We walked by on a Thursday evening, liked the menu and decided to give it...
review_full: Talking to the owner at the end of our meal I learnt that this family run place had been in existence for thirty years but this was our first discovery. We walked by on a Thursday evening, liked the menu and decided to give it a go. As it had been fairly quiet we didn't make a reservation and turned up on the next night. Luckily we turned up early ( by spanish standards) and were given a table. Within half an hour every table was taken. Service was slick and we were asked if we wanted an aperitif when the menus were delivered, always a good sign. The choice of food is superb as is the food itself. One nice touch was that they willingly changed fried potatoes for rice to accompany the meatballs which my wife had chosen. Maybe the wine list was a bit on the pricey side but not so as to detract from an overall wonderful experience. We shall return.

Then we could go in. Keep in mind, at first, the personnel may seem a bit rude but its just a little bustling place so they're busy constantly. They're friendly and considerate, yet loud when passing through orders, it's part of the experience . The food was just perfect and truly delicious. The prices are actually economically friendly. A bottle of water, an aged red wine, the malaspina tapas and potatoes with garlic and spicy sauce altogether cost us 15€.

review_preview: Excellent service and marvellous food. This is a foodies dream and a restaurant that provides the best of seasonal produce available from Spain.Note, you should book in advance and not rely upon getting a table, as many people think they can stay at the...
review_full: Excellent service and marvellous food. This is a foodies dream and a restaurant that provides the best of seasonal produce available from Spain. Note, you should book in advance and not rely upon getting a table, as many people think they can stay at the Hotel next door and get a table at Dos Cielos however, the restaurant is very popular with locals... So book in advance otherwise you'll be disappointed. If you're looking for a big feed huge portion restaurant, this won't be for you, this is fine dining at it's peak with subtle flavours and technically brilliant cooking. All the dishes on the tasting menu were excellent, but the spring goat was superb and really stood out as a favourite for us. Service was excellent with plenty of attentive staff and even the chef came to say hello. If you're in Madrid well worth eating here.

title_review: Nice traditional fare with white linen
review_preview: Went here with a friend after being away from Madrid for a long time.  Was pleased overall with the meal, sampling their partridge salad and garlic shrimp as starters, with sea bass as the main course.  After spending my summer eating the freshest possible fish...
review_full: Went here with a friend after being away from Madrid for a long time. Was pleased overall with the meal, sampling their partridge salad and garlic shrimp as starters, with sea bass as the main course. After spending my summer eating the freshest possible fish in Galicia, I was unsure about the quality of fish we would be served. I can honestly say it is one of the best pieces of fish that I've eaten in my life - extremely fresh and perfectly done, simply accompanied by garlic and olive oil. Next time I want to try the milanesa (breaded cutlet), which looks to be the house specialty. Only complaint is that it's a tad on the pricey side, particularly the garlic shrimp. That said, the quality and service were excellent. Well done!

review_preview: We went to Casa Gallega on our last night in Madrid.  It was recommended by our hotel staff and I loved it.  They specialize in fish but we decided to try the meat options...pork or lamb roasted in a wood fired oven.  I chose the...
review_full: We went to Casa Gallega on our last night in Madrid. It was recommended by our hotel staff and I loved it. They specialize in fish but we decided to try the meat options...pork or lamb roasted in a wood fired oven. I chose the lamb and my friend chose the pork. It was delicious. Waiters didn’t speak English but with my broken Spanish and the help of one of the women who works there we did just fine. The food was excellent and the staff was very friendly. One thing to note, the portions are huge. For the meat dishes you can order for 1 or 2 (i.e. pork for 2 or 1). We had a great time at this restaurant and I would definitely go back.

review_full: Don't expect a standard restaurant where you take your seat and will be waited on by a person who has a number of other tables to take care of. Not only will he recommend and explain the items on the hand-written menu but will also prepare and assist you in the preparation of the individual items that make your mouth water. The line in front of the restaurant quickly gets longer and longer. Reservations cannot be made.

review_preview: Amazing foodie experience, unique in many ways. It can get really really busy, so don't be surprised! Find a spot on the counter or against the wall, then one of the waiters will be available to help you. There are no tables & chairs -...
review_full: Amazing foodie experience, unique in many ways. It can get really really busy, so don't be surprised! Find a spot on the counter or against the wall, then one of the waiters will be available to help you. There are no tables & chairs - not a regular restaurant, decor is really interesting, kinda funky. Menu is Spanish (no English translation) an incredible range of tapas selections. Luckily our server spoke pretty good English. Lots of locals! We went to dinner arriving around 7 pm when it wasn't to busy. Signature dishes: Beef Tartar spread everything offered on each slice & roll it up....the giant tomato with basil...we had around 15 different menu options. Nothing is served on a plate everything comes out on a type of baking paper so if table cloths and silverware is something you need, this dining adventure is not for you. We had so much fun, one of our best European dinners.

review_preview: We had reserved the long table seating for dinner. The idea of eating at the counter was not appealing to us.The food was very fusion (think Japanese style with Spanish ingredients) and creative in presentation. We are used to these restaurants in Asia so...
review_full: We had reserved the long table seating for dinner. The idea of eating at the counter was not appealing to us. The food was very fusion (think Japanese style with Spanish ingredients) and creative in presentation. We are used to these restaurants in Asia so nothing came as a surprise. Having said that I loved the meat they served which was of top quality.  The one-man band waiter (a very talkative fellow!) tried his best to serve all twelve guests at the large communal table. Like a Japanese sushi chef, he used a mini fire torch to grill raw beef right in front of us in the tiny gap between the diners. He also served wine like a sommelier. A true asset to any restaurant I must say. To talk (about what) or not to talk with the fellow diners at the long table was stressful enough. The space was cramp and minimalist. It reminded me of the back kitchen of a butcher house. We were aware of the set up before we booked. But to be actually sitting in there was another story altogether. I had wanted to leave the moment we sat down. Our dining experience lasted 40 minutes, and we finished up and left. The bill for two with two glasses of house wine came to be 95€. Not cheap at all for a quick dinner.  On our way out, we saw a queue forming outside the tiny restaurant. I would not visit it the second time for sure.

review_preview: As a family of 4, we have done 5 Michelin stars restaurants in Spain over the past 2 weeks (Mugaritz, Azurmendi, Disfrutar, Enigma, Ricard Camarena) so we have a pretty good understanding of the Michelin stars in Spain.The place was recommended to us by...
review_full: As a family of 4, we have done 5 Michelin stars restaurants in Spain over the past 2 weeks (Mugaritz, Azurmendi, Disfrutar, Enigma, Ricard Camarena) so we have a pretty good understanding of the Michelin stars in Spain. The place was recommended to us by a local friend. Quite a few of the dishes from Sala de Despiece would without a doubt fit 100% in a Michelin star menu. Yes the music is louder than necessary (and I usually hate that) but the food both in terms of presentation and taste and the service is so much above what you would expect from a small counter serving place that is easy to accept the music. I guess if the setting was more "fine dining" like (no stereotypical loud American tourist telling her life story 5 seats away at counter, table dining, soft music, ambiance lighting etc....) the place would get one Michelin star. I am not suggesting in any way that they should move towards the fine dining setting as it is a great to have such place where the food is so much better than what the setting would suggest. It is as if people below who rated it "terrible" are talking about another place. We will definitely come back next time we are in Madrid. Highly recommended.

The server was a very nice gentleman and we left it up to him to suggest their signature dishes and he was spot on. He started us with chuleton cenital which is thin slices of meat with two different spreads almost like a tartar. It was delicious. Then he served us a large heirloom tomato topped with crispy basil drizzled with olive oil. It was incredibly juicy and tasty. We moved to Navajas plancha(razor clams) and then seared tuna and plate of grilled cheese all delicious and well prepared. All of the above were served with glasses of chardonnay.

EVERYTHING we tried was outstanding, including the bottle of a good crianza Rioja. The fish (bonito), the solomillo (TRY PLEASE, is out of this world), the burratta, the beef (bonbon, cooked in front of you with a himalaya salt stone, served with raspberries AND the dessert, deserves a standing ovation.  we even had the pleasure to chat with the owner and creator of the concept (Ivan), who gently took the time to explain the reasons behind this unique venue, after his years living in Milan and Tokio.  GO GO GO, and don´t panic....be patient and the rest will easily come!!!
