We were there for about an hour, came back at 10:30 and although it wasn't quite as busy, it was still busy. We found one chair and never got another one, even over an hour later. An older Spanish group were telling us exactly what to try (at this point it is midnight)! Everything we tried - navajas, potato, and the egg with truffles was really good. Really hip ambiance and a fun place to be on a Wednesday night. I can't imagine what this place is like on the weekends! Would love to go again to find out.

review_full: The one reason I don't rate this place as 5 stars is because it's so packed it's very difficult to enjoy whatever one's having, never mind the company and chat :) We asked one of the waiters when could we go so as to enjoy the offerings and the atmosphere, and he said we could wait up at the door for them to open at 1pm and then we could place ourseves in the corner and enjoy! He said that with a friendly smile, and a sort of 'I'm sorry about the masses' face, in a way that we found endearing! Service was efficient, fast, friendly -- impeccable, I would say, considering the hordes of customers. Prices was totally fine for what we had, I'm not sure why other reviewers say it's overpriced, in my opinion it's probably just the opposite. What we had, "alcarchofas" and "cecina", was really really good. Kudos to this original and innovative place. (I digged the pass through under the main table!)

review_preview: I must admit I found this place through a YouTube video. It was a great suggestion. I made a reservation but did not know what I was up to. There are two parts to the place: one where customers are served on a first-come-first-serve basis...
review_full: I must admit I found this place through a YouTube video. It was a great suggestion. I made a reservation but did not know what I was up to. There are two parts to the place: one where customers are served on a first-come-first-serve basis and a separate one where access is gained through reservations. When we arrived we were quickly escorted back on the street and then to a small door and to another through a rickety corridor. The door opens into a small room where a large white lucite table lit from below can host the whole of 12 people. The room is a former butcher’s refrigerator with insulated quilted walls and a red rubber floor, a very original place one would expect in Berlin. The food is ordered and served a la carte, each portion with a certain price , sushi-style. Our server (was he the chef, too?) was very attentive and choreographed how each portion should be eaten to all of us. The food was terrific and creative and you tell a lot of thought had gone into it. There are two seatings, at least, for dinner: in the end it became clear that the waiter was late for the next shift and we felt rushed. Dessert came without berries and literally on the way out. In spite of this glitch this is a place I would recommend to anyone interested in more contemporary and creative assortments and presentations of food.

review_preview: This is a long, narrow, very tall room, the seating area about the width of a railway carriage, with dreadful decor. Walls with covering that has the appearance of cheap corkboard, the main long wall facing the bar covered with huge photographs of seafood which...
review_full: This is a long, narrow, very tall room, the seating area about the width of a railway carriage, with dreadful decor. Walls with covering that has the appearance of cheap corkboard, the main long wall facing the bar covered with huge photographs of seafood which only serve to emphasise the awkward shape of the room. Initially, we were alone and asked for the very loud disco music (BeeGees!) to be turned down. The tall thin (one of two) girl said she would, until more customers came in, when she would have to raise the volume so that neighbours could not overhear each other's conversations - now that's an original excuse! The lighting is appalling, glaring and bright, and very unflattering. Indeed as the place filled up it became very noisy, the shape of the room making for poor acoustics. What about the food? Well - that's ok, even pretty good. Trendy tiny portions on trendy china or slate, and prices in inverse proportion to the portions. This is my idea of hell in catering - pretentious, arrogant and with no attempt to make the experience a good one for the client. I rate the service as "poor" because of the arrogance. Grudgingly give food a "very good" rather than "average".

title_review: V(ery)i (Un)Cool - rude staff and worst customer service in Madrid
review_preview: The customer experience in this place is the worst we have experienced in two months staying in Madrid. Having booked a table for 10pm, we arrived at the door to be greeted by nobody and eventually walked up the a lady who seemed to be...
review_full: The customer experience in this place is the worst we have experienced in two months staying in Madrid. Having booked a table for 10pm, we arrived at the door to be greeted by nobody and eventually walked up the a lady who seemed to be dealing with seating guests. We announced that we had made a reservation for 2 people at 10pm to be told sternly that she had no record of the reservation. I produced email evidence showing that the restaurant had confirmed the reservation, at which the lady made us feel like it was somehow our fault and tried to shift attention to the fact that sometimes guests receive an automated email but that does not guarantee reservation. So I then showed her both the automated email and the follow up one CONFIRMING the reservation, at which point there was still no apology and the best they could do was offer us a place at the bar (still no apology) and try to seat us within half an hour. Needless to say, I made my feelings clear to the lady and walked out given that a restaurant like this never deserves to have the custom of people it treats with such disdain. It's one thing to make an error with the reservation, and another to be rude to them and make them feel as if it's somehow your fault for trying to book in advance and eat at their restaurant. Do yourself a favour and go somewhere for dinner that is capable of honouring its reservations and when it makes a mistake, actually apologises and tries to do something positive about it.

At the end when we left it was filled with tourists only - that's a bad sign too. Locals don't come here and I can see why. The food was just bad. Very expensive and bad, which is the worst. The waiters were very nice and did their best, you gotta give them that. But really, a waste of a lot of money.

review_preview: I went to day for the Menu del Dia and while not the cheapest in town, you do often get what you pay for. The menu itself was 13.50 Euros I believe. The daily menu changes each week so I won't go into details but...
review_full: I went to day for the Menu del Dia and while not the cheapest in town, you do often get what you pay for. The menu itself was 13.50 Euros I believe. The daily menu changes each week so I won't go into details but the food was well prepared, well presented, and the service was spot on. Unlike the majority of menus, this one doesn't include a bebida (drink) so you have to pay for wine, beer, or mineral water so it does drive the price up (I had two glasses of wine and a bottle of mineral water so my total was 27 Euros). That being said, this isn't your standard menu del dia, it's a step up in quality from what you will find most places. Great decor/interior of the restaurant too. Highly recommended.

review_preview: Tapas with a touch of trendy cuisine. This is what my husband and I experienced at the restaurant called Vi Cool, in a narrow street almost at the "Plaza Angel", in central Madrid.The whole are seems becoming a bit trendy, with this street, called...
review_full: Tapas with a touch of trendy cuisine. This is what my husband and I experienced at the restaurant called Vi Cool, in a narrow street almost at the "Plaza Angel", in central Madrid. The whole are seems becoming a bit trendy, with this street, called Huertas having a good number of restaurants and small shops. Vo Cool has a number of "bacadillos", small dishes, all very well prepared and delicious. We had one bite potatoes cakes ("patatas bravas"), fried shrimps with curry and mint flavours, meatballs with a sauce of melted "mancheco" cheese and a kind of small sandwich of fois gras. We cannot complain, since everything was good. The waiters were nice and the kitchen was fast on delivering the dishes. The only thing a bit snobbish is that the manager already gave your limite time at the restaurant when you are sitting.

title_review: Shh!!! A catalan restaurant in the heart of Madrid! Don't tell anyone!
review_preview: This place rocks! After a few days in Madrid, the Castilian flavors start to become familiar and most madrilian restaurants, have a very peculiar similar taste; that is, until you arrive at Vi Cool! Yes, a tear was shed as I tasted their patatas bravas,...
review_full: This place rocks! After a few days in Madrid, the Castilian flavors start to become familiar and most madrilian restaurants, have a very peculiar similar taste; that is, until you arrive at Vi Cool! Yes, a tear was shed as I tasted their patatas bravas, then it made sense, I remembered the name "Vi" means wine in Catalan, I closed my eyes and felt as if I was eating in one of the best restaurants in Barcelona. By the way, their Patatas Bravas were once selected among the Top 10 patatas bravas in Spain. This place is awesome, the service outstanding and the food Top 10. Not to miss!

title_review: It was my accidental discovery, to be proud off :) Highly recommended!!
review_preview: This time around, I was staying in Madrid only overnight, to catch a morning flight to Amsterdam the next day.  I was staying in an airport hotel, but, of course, wanted to say hi to Madrid. And so, after walking around, I came to Puerta...
review_full: This time around, I was staying in Madrid only overnight, to catch a morning flight to Amsterdam the next day. I was staying in an airport hotel, but, of course, wanted to say hi to Madrid. And so, after walking around, I came to Puerta del Sol, in search of great restaurant I ate in last year. Could not find it, but stumbled, literally, into Taberna de Dsecubierta. A GREAT FIND!! I sat at the table next to the window, so had a full view of the street :)  The service was wonderfully efficient and friendly. The food was great, and a glass of good dry house wine was only 1.60 euro. Had a great evening. Will come back, when in Madrid :) THANKS :)

title_review: Some excellent tapas and great wine
review_preview: We had some interesting and excellent tapas here on a cold January night. The red wine was excellent too.  We went with the Tapas classic menu, that is an easy selection to make. The bread and salsa to start with was great.  The Carpaccio Portobello...
review_full: We had some interesting and excellent tapas here on a cold January night. The red wine was excellent too. We went with the Tapas classic menu, that is an easy selection to make. The bread and salsa to start with was great. The Carpaccio Portobello was excellent very nice light truffle flavoring. The Burrata cheese salad with beets was very good. The bravas potatoes were excellent. The stewed meatballs were very good. The final hot dish was the Chicken wings with a kimchi flavoring and it was good (just good). The dessert was excellent with two different flavors for us to sample. Service was friendly.

title_review: Well worth it - top of the list!
review_preview: Amazing tapas, with even better service - reservations highly recommended. Quality of the food: ingredients and presentation were superb. Other diners were a good mix of locals and foreigners - shows that it’s high up there for local standards, but also has the additional ‘wow’...
review_full: Amazing tapas, with even better service - reservations highly recommended. Quality of the food: ingredients and presentation were superb. Other diners were a good mix of locals and foreigners - shows that it’s high up there for local standards, but also has the additional ‘wow’ factor to attract tourists, like us, who may be only visiting for a few days and have limited meals they can have in a culinary centre like Madrid. So it’s tough competition, but these guys end up on top. Highly recommend the foie gras, octopus carpaccio, pizzas (yes, their own style!) and the crunchy oxtail. Wash it down with a couple glasses of cava and Tempranillo!

The dining experience itself was lovely although more expensive than most restraints however you do get what you pay for. We would return should we visit Madrid again. I recommend the potatas bravas for a cool twist and the ‘textured chocolate’ if you can be tempted into pudding.

title_review: Great food, very affordable, smack dab in the middle of old Madrid
review_preview: Rare to find lovely food in the middle of touristy old Madrid at such affordable prices! I recommend the menu, which gives you a flavour of everything and is probably suited to everyone’s taste pallette - with classics (meat balls, patatas, chicken wings, cream catalana)...
review_full: Rare to find lovely food in the middle of touristy old Madrid at such affordable prices! I recommend the menu, which gives you a flavour of everything and is probably suited to everyone’s taste pallette - with classics (meat balls, patatas, chicken wings, cream catalana) done in sublime modern ways. Don’t expect unusual flavours, but very tasty twists on Spanish tablestakes. Service is friendly, unpretentious and professional. Book ahead if you can!

title_review: Spanish food as it should be
review_preview: This restaurant has been in Madrid for many years . It was reputed to be a favourite of Hemingway during his stays in the capital .It serves very traditional Spanish food with a good range of vegetable , fish and meat dishes . The restaurant...
review_full: This restaurant has been in Madrid for many years . It was reputed to be a favourite of Hemingway during his stays in the capital .It serves very traditional Spanish food with a good range of vegetable , fish and meat dishes . The restaurant comprises a number of small discrete rooms and corners spread over two floors which guarantees a certain amount of privacy . For those who have an interest in bullfighting the restaurant contains a remarkable collection of paintings , photographs and etchings with all the great bullfighters visible .. Really worth a visit either for lunch or dinner

title_review: Wow! Great traditional food and atmosphere!
review_preview: The staff was very friendly and helpful especially with our limited Spanish and their limited English. The old rustic interior helped us settle into traditional Spanish meal mode. Old paintings and pictures of bullfighting and Hemingway on the walls . Food was no frills, simple,...
review_full: The staff was very friendly and helpful especially with our limited Spanish and their limited English. The old rustic interior helped us settle into traditional Spanish meal mode. Old paintings and pictures of bullfighting and Hemingway on the walls . Food was no frills, simple, and most importantly, delicious.  Started off great with some croquettes and vermouth. Although the rabo de toro was great (tender and fall off the bone), the breaded hake fish was our favorite. Just the right tenderness and simple seasoning. A must have! The fried chicken with sauce paired with garlic cauliflower was also good. Our party also had veal steaks which were tender and juicy. My son doesn’t normally finish a steak in the 8 to 12 ounce size but he finished his steak no problem. As always in Spain in general, potatoes are done well and crispy. Would recommend the pistachio ice cream for dessert. The flan was a little stiffer than we’re used to. Must be a Madrid thing.  I have to admit that the menu isn’t really a fancy gastronomic breakthrough by modern restaurant standards, the food was simply delicious and well-prepared with pride and love.  Will definitely come back for the hake our next time in Madrid.

review_preview: About the food.  'Modern' or 'fusion' crusines are more than plenty in a metropolis like Madrid, but tranditional local food eateries are rare.  In Casa Salvador we have found a pleasant experience in traditional flavor, and had every supper here during our stay.  The dishes...
review_full: About the food. 'Modern' or 'fusion' crusines are more than plenty in a metropolis like Madrid, but tranditional local food eateries are rare. In Casa Salvador we have found a pleasant experience in traditional flavor, and had every supper here during our stay. The dishes are simple, some may not even appear fascnating, but they are all genuine and nice. In Madrid, you have to try at least once, to eat like a local. About their service. It's not a Michelin with professional waiters. It's more like a little neigbourhood bistro, staffed all by family members. The waiter, a gentleman, acutally does not speak or understand much English, but he's very helpful and eager to offer what he can best provide. During our first visit he mistook a dish we ordered and said the other dish we ordered was sold out (in fact not, but, interestingly, the two substitute dishes were equally good). The lady in charge speaks good English, so during our next visit, we double-checked with her after fixing the order with the gentleman. The gentleman was still sorry about the mistake yesterday, and he was apparently very happy that we visited again. We enjoyed the suppers there, the mistakes are only an interesting part of experience of travelling in a foreign country and exploring new flavors. They provide half-size dishes, so you can try more varieties at one time. About the environment. Small room decorated with old bull-fighting photos.  In all, we love those people, and we wish more visitors can try their food. They are 3 mins walk away from the Chueca metro station, and 5 mins from the Cibeles Plaza.

review_preview: This is by far one of the best restaurants in Madrid. It's in the center of the city, close to plaza de Santa Ana. They offer traditional Andalusian dishes. The place is very cozy, the service is excellent. They serve appetizers that are on the...
review_full: This is by far one of the best restaurants in Madrid. It's in the center of the city, close to plaza de Santa Ana. They offer traditional Andalusian dishes. The place is very cozy, the service is excellent. They serve appetizers that are on the house. Another positive is that the portions are quite big. We ordered a salad, salmon tapas and baby squids and couldn't eat all of it despite everything being so delicious. And on top of all - the prices. Everything is a bit less expensive than the other restaurants in Central Madrid. We had a great dinner experience overall and strongly recommend this place. PS: The draft bier (I am not sure but I think they brew it themselves) was the best I had for 5 days on Madrid.

title_review: unfair food distribution, poor taste, poor service
review_preview: I am a university professor from the US, and have visited well over 50 countries in my lifetime as an adult. I also love exploring food. I usually do not contribute to reviews unless it is either exceptionally terrible or terrific. This review, unfortunately, is...
review_full: I am a university professor from the US, and have visited well over 50 countries in my lifetime as an adult. I also love exploring food. I usually do not contribute to reviews unless it is either exceptionally terrible or terrific. This review, unfortunately, is a terrible review. We ordered the foot-high seafood platter and an octopus dish when we visited this restaurant yesterday. The octopus itself was the softest octopus we have tasted in all of Spain (a huge plus); however, it was rather bland (for taste, you should definitely try it at the Mercado de San Miguel). As for the seafood platter, we were very disappointed. We started with a great deal of excitement, but felt the taste was not nearly as good as what other reviews had stated - tasted like frozen seafood. Looking around at other tables (the restaurant was fairly full) to see how much others are enjoying the same dish (because practically everyone ordered the same seafood platter - their signature dish), I came to notice two major differences (check our photos with those of others or on their website). First, while others had snow and dungeness crabs, we were served only one snow crab, and they filled the platter with snow crab legs rather than what should have been dungeness crab. Second, we were given two very small crabs (resembling blue crabs) while others were given what appeared to have been stone crabs (the ones with huge claws). I kept looking around, and we were the only one among dozens with such a difference. I asked to speak with someone who could speak English. A staff member arrived and was trying to explain with broken English which I could not understand. We left the place very disappointed. Staff was not helpful and very unapologetic - this was unfortunate which prompted me to share this review. Those who decide to venture after reading this review, I hope your experience is a positive one. For us, it left a sour taste in our mouth...a very unpleasant experience while in Madrid...and, hopefully, the only one.

title_review: A taste of Arola's cuisine at a fraction of the price
review_preview: Even though this is top chef Sergi Arola's "B" restaurant, I have been meaning to try it for some time since the prices are much more humane than at Arola's premiere restaurant.  The staff is very nice and attentive.  I decided to try the 20...
review_full: Even though this is top chef Sergi Arola's "B" restaurant, I have been meaning to try it for some time since the prices are much more humane than at Arola's premiere restaurant. The staff is very nice and attentive. I decided to try the 20 euro Tapas Menu to get a good sampling of the restaurant's dishes, and while all in all it was a good experience, the dishes were uneven. The most pedestrian and almost tasteless offering was the first: sliced portobello mushrooms marinated with truffle oil and served with Parmesan cheese and pine nuts. But again, that was the first dish, and they seemed to get better from there. Especially wonderful are the Patatas Bravas a la "Arola", which are really nicely spiced and are more like twice baked stuff potatoes. It was unique to be served a number of chicken wings, but these just didn't deliver much compared to American spicy "Buffalo-style wings." The dark chocolate fondue with fresh cut fruit was delicious. The decor is tasteful and modern though the soundtrack with Portishead/Morcheeba type music is beginning to feel redundant: it seems such hipster music has become standard at modern Bistros like this. Do note, the menus DO NOT come with drinks so you should expect to pay a pretty penny/euro for your wine and coffee.

review_preview: Having dined all over the world including at numerous Michelin-starred restaurants, there are few places you could enjoy a six course tasting menu of this quality and creativity for 22 Euros a person.  We arrived early at 8pm without a reservation (you definitely need one...
review_full: Having dined all over the world including at numerous Michelin-starred restaurants, there are few places you could enjoy a six course tasting menu of this quality and creativity for 22 Euros a person. We arrived early at 8pm without a reservation (you definitely need one in season or on weekends). The friendly and elegant proprietress graciously offered us a two top in the main dining room with the condition that we vacate by 10pm. This was fine with us since we’d been traveling for 36 hours and planned to turn in early. (I observed her accommodate many tourists and locals alike with the same friendly smile.) We started our meal with a couple of house gin and tonics, which arrived in fishbowl sized glasses elegantly garnished with basil leaves. Delicious and refreshing, even in November. We chose the traditional 22 Euro tapas menu over the 36 Euro seafood menu because we had enjoyed seafood for lunch. Out came the first course- chilled mushroom carpaccio with parmesan and white truffle oil generously drizzled over the top. This first dish really summed up what this place is all about- transforming honest, local ingredients into unexpected delights. At this point, we ordered a bottle of Rioja, which at 29 Euros was a solid complement to our budget friendly meal. The second course of burrata, shredded red cabbage, and beets was equally creative yet satisfying. The creamy texture of the burrata paired perfectly with the salty, soy marinated beets. Next, we enjoyed juicy and rich meatballs with Vi Cool’s signature version of traditional patatas bravas, elegantly presented as a rolled canape topped with a petite dollop of creamy aioli. Even in this elevated form, the potatoes were crispy on the outside and deliciously creamy inside. Though we were already full at this point, there was yet another tapas to enjoy- chicken drumettes, lightly fried and topped with sliced scallions. Dessert arrived in a pair of shot glasses. The waiter explained that the dish was best enjoyed in proper order. First, the pineapple rosemary pudding/cream (my favorite) followed by the dulce de leche. Both were amazing. In summary, the quality of the food was excellent and the service prompt and friendly. The value was exceptional. I would definitely recommend this tapas restaurant to anyone staying in central Madrid, or visiting the Museo del Prado, as the restaurant is an easy 10-minute walk (up Calle de Huertas) from the museum.

review_preview: Run, I tell you, run, to Vi Cool. My only regret is that we could only enjoy one meal there as we are on the go tomorrow.This restaurant does everything right: the tapas are sublime, the table is super comfortable and the wait staff...
review_full: Run, I tell you, run, to Vi Cool. My only regret is that we could only enjoy one meal there as we are on the go tomorrow. This restaurant does everything right: the tapas are sublime, the table is super comfortable and the wait staff is generous in their assistance to diners. There is no way that you can go wrong here. We had the tasting menu which was extraordinarily tasty. Often, with such a menu, there will be something mediocre thrown in. Not here! Lovely mushrooms, beets and a soft cheese, meatballs with a sauce that hints of roquerfort(don't knock it until you try it), just spicey enough chicken wings and their signature, potatoes brava, are all served up to perfection. Oh! And the toasty bread with some kind of tomato sauce. There is no way that you will not be satisfied here. I only wish that I could take this place with me in my future travels. Bravo!

review_preview: The best restaurant we visited in our trip to Madrid. Menus are available in English. Service is very traditional with older male waiters.I had the fried calamari starter and hake in garlic with a salad instead of potatoes. My husband had octopus then turbot...
review_full: The best restaurant we visited in our trip to Madrid. Menus are available in English. Service is very traditional with older male waiters. I had the fried calamari starter and hake in garlic with a salad instead of potatoes. My husband had octopus then turbot Gallicean(?) style. Our starters were extremely generous and could be a main meal in themselves! The mains were cooked to perfection and again well sized, although if you are only having a main, you might like to order a side as well. For dessert my husband ordered a Souffle Alaska which was HUGE and flambed at the table, a lot of fun. I had a more sedate almond cake which was wonderfully moist. Lovely traditional service, fantastic food. Will definitely visit again if we return to Madrid!

review_preview: This traditional Galician restaurant looks as if it has been around for decades, judging by the old fashioned decor (think Santiago de Compostela, circa 1972), and the approach of its staff, which, while professional, may well come across as surly, especially if you don't speak...
review_full: This traditional Galician restaurant looks as if it has been around for decades, judging by the old fashioned decor (think Santiago de Compostela, circa 1972), and the approach of its staff, which, while professional, may well come across as surly, especially if you don't speak Spanish. But you come here for the food - fresh fish and seafood cooked Galician style, with plenty of rich olive oil, firm potatoes and lots of the typically Spanish paprika known as pimenton. In our case, we let our waiter do the picking, asking for a selection of typical Galician dishes to share with tourists that know nothing about that part of northern Spain. And we were in for a treat: empanadas gallegas to start off, followed by mussels in a creamy sauce, pulpo a la gallega (the signature dish), merluza a la gallega, bacalao al horno, lubina a la espalda ... All washed down by a very pleasant (and reasonably priced) Albarino white wine. So, my advice is to go local - ask the waiters (one or two can manage in English - be patient) for Galician recommendations. Then sit back and enjoy.

So I really consider this restaurant a little pricey, but it's centrally located in a touristic environnement so I should maybe be expecting it.

Putting aside the 'brands' of Arola and Adriá, I didn't find anything particularly impressive about this restaurant. The design is strange...half restaurant..half warehouse wall. Some of the alcohol bottles were kept were on a counter by the customer tables, like at a house party. The food was average, the portions small and the prices slightly too high for what you get. The service was ok. I would give this place a miss.

review_preview: We were walking around on a Friday night trying to find a place to eat, when we stumbled upon Vi Cool. We were a bit sceptic at first, as the prices seemed relatively high from the display outside the door, but when we came in...
review_full: We were walking around on a Friday night trying to find a place to eat, when we stumbled upon Vi Cool. We were a bit sceptic at first, as the prices seemed relatively high from the display outside the door, but when we came in and were seated, they had both a la carte and menus at reasonable prices. We were asked if it was okay to sit in the basement and were offered to check it out before deciding. We decided it was okay, so we were seated there. We started off with a Mojito, which was not quite to my taste with pineapple, but was nicely made. We ordered 3 orders of the classic tapas menu (three people there), which was incredible! It is not much like traditional small tapas dishes, but a modern interpretation of the traditional tastes. Very delicious, and a perfect amount of food. The menu, when we were there, consisted of three cold dishes, three warm dishes and a dessert for €22, which was very reasonable for the amount and quality of the food. The drinks were a bit more expensive than what we had otherwise had in Madrid, but still not outrageous. Certainly a place I would consider returning to, and can happily recommend to others.

review_preview: This place seems to be the latest trendy Tapas Restaurant amongst Madrilenos. Was recommended it by a couple of locals. First, get there EARLY. As you will know most Spaniards eat around 9pm but if you don't want to wait in a queue and get...
review_full: This place seems to be the latest trendy Tapas Restaurant amongst Madrilenos. Was recommended it by a couple of locals.  First, get there EARLY. As you will know most Spaniards eat around 9pm but if you don't want to wait in a queue and get a good seat come at around 8 or 8.30 before it actually opens.  It is great if you want to have some tapas and wine but don't plan on staying to long as the large crowds gathering, the noise, and the pushing will shortly irriate you. So would not recommend for a romantic meal. However the food is great, brilliantly prepared un front of you using unusual techniques but the taste is definitely there. They have brilliant wines too.  The slaughterhouse environment is actually quite fun. Not the cheapest place for tapas though but again you pay for the experience. Worth a visit.

The chefs are polite and freindly as is the waiter and we were recommended good wines and some excellent tapas. I was lucky to find a seat even if it was a bit cramped and my partner eventualy got a seat. If this is midweek then weekends must be unbeliviably busy. Will i go again certainly its not usualy my sort of thing but i was captivated by the whole experience so please do go if your in the chamberi area.

title_review: Great seafood - fresh from the tank!

The Octopus was excellent, and the grilled seafood platter out of this world. The poached seafood platter, especially the crab and lobsters which came straight from the tank, was great, It's best to ask for portions that would be appropriate for the number in your group, otherwise it will be too much. The waiters was very attentive and recommended well. Service was more than excellent and our group will long remember this place and come back when we are in Madrid.

review_preview: We visited Casa Gallega on a Sunday; the place, centrally located, was crowded with local guests, until late in the afternoon. The food was simply superb; fish and seafood was tasty and well presented, and we could choose amongst a wide range of Galician specialities....
review_full: We visited Casa Gallega on a Sunday; the place, centrally located, was crowded with local guests, until late in the afternoon. The food was simply superb; fish and seafood was tasty and well presented, and we could choose amongst a wide range of Galician specialities.  The place is clean and quite traditional, a jump back in the 70's, no fashionable design but you will feel at home, surrounded by joyful small groups of locals celebrating events.  The service was very efficient, the maitre himself advised with enthusiasm and patience the daily specialities (our Spanish is only basic).  Relatively expensive, but absolutely worth the experience. Looking forward to coming back!  PS: The right address of Casa Gallega is Calle Bordadores, 11

review_preview: We like the food. It's very good and very creative that it's worth visiting. This restaurant also does great fusion tapas, which is not very common as most fusion tapas we discovered were not quite there yet. We also like the wine list as they...
review_full: We like the food. It's very good and very creative that it's worth visiting. This restaurant also does great fusion tapas, which is not very common as most fusion tapas we discovered were not quite there yet. We also like the wine list as they offer very interesting choices. So as food enthusiast, we have returned every now and then when we are looking for a light meal.  Now for warnings: This is a place for young crowd in search of rare interesting food and drinks in chic atmosphere. It is not a place for elderly tourist who seek a hearty big course meal with comfortable seating.  Also as stated earlier, service in this place is aloof at best, bored and distant at worst. However, considering the fame of the star chef, it is not a surprise. Most restaurants in Spain with superstar chefs, with only a few as exceptions, are somewhat guarantee to give you standoffish service in varying degrees. The bill is not coming cheap either which is again normal to a restaurant of this fame.  So the verdict is If you are on a budget, want some comfort and TLC with a belly filling meal then this is not for you. However if you are the "I will go anywhere, try anything once" for food that delights your palate then go ahead you won't be disappointed.

review_full: One of my favorite places -if not the favorite- in Madrid! Great location, great presentation of the dishes, the staff is nice, the decor is original, but obviously it's the food that makes me go back every time I am in Madrid! The bravas are delicious, just like the cheese croquetas, the eggplant.. As a vegetarian I sometimes find it difficult to dine out in Madrid, but this place has a lot of (amazing) tapas that I can eat.  It's located in a small street not far from Plaza Santa Ana, and it's really worth a try for everyone who wants to discover typical Spanish food made by a recognized and inspired chef, and for a very good price.

review_preview: My daughter and I dined at Casa Gallega while visiting Madrid this May.  We had already done Tapas restaurants and an evening at the San Miguel Market.   We were looking for a quiet place for a nice meal, sitting down!, since previous nights involved dining...
review_full: My daughter and I dined at Casa Gallega while visiting Madrid this May. We had already done Tapas restaurants and an evening at the San Miguel Market. We were looking for a quiet place for a nice meal, sitting down!, since previous nights involved dining standing up in crowded areas. Casa Gallega did not disappoint. Centrally located near Plaza Mayor, it is a nice seafood restaurant. We enjoyed two huge meals, could not possibly eat it all, for 70 euros. This included 2 appetizers each, an entree each, dessert, coffee, and about 3 glasses of wine each. This was their menu of the day special. Service was wonderful and the food was good. My daughter doesn't like octopus but found theirs quite delicious. This restaurant is worth a try if you want to get away from the hustle and bustle of the touristy restaurants and you want some fresh seafood.

review_preview: Years ago, whenever I was in Madrid, I loved having lunch at this genuinely Galician restaurant tucked away in the shadow of the Plaza Mayor, it was my favorite in the city. On my recent trip I couldn’t find it, went around the neighborhood searching...
review_full: Years ago, whenever I was in Madrid, I loved having lunch at this genuinely Galician restaurant tucked away in the shadow of the Plaza Mayor, it was my favorite in the city. On my recent trip I couldn’t find it, went around the neighborhood searching and was finally directed to its new location several blocks away. I arrived at the door and asked if it would be possible to have lunch that day and received a very lukewarm response. The restaurant was virtually empty and I was received by the haughtiest maitre d‘ this side of a Hollywood casting studio and was shown to the worst table in the dining room. Menu appeared and there was the dish I had been longing for since I arrived: 'Pulpo a la Gallega'. I ordered it along with Caldo Gallego and a half bottle of Ribiero and sat back ignoring the fact that though several staff were standing around watching none of them would glance my way or approach the table. The Maitre d‘ glared at my table whenever he passed through to the kitchen, but no water glass was refilled nor was my wine poured for me... once the food arrived I was left to it. The Caldo was not anything special, however the pulpo was--it was amazing, and I cleaned a large plate filled with it and could probably have eaten more. As I ate tables began to fill, and the staff and Maitre d’ became increasingly more nervous at my presence. I on the other hand was enjoying myself, and the situation, and I stretched my wine out as long as I reasonably could. Ordered flan for dessert, it was only so-so but it allowed me to sit at the table a bit longer. By the time I was finished the restaurant was largely filled and I was fascinated to see the clientele... 25 years ago one mostly saw a mix of working-class, middle-class and tourists eating at the Gallega, but now it was filled with elegant Madrileños, seemed almost like a private club. I could understand why the management was so impatient for me to leave, and I would have felt a little sympathy if they hadn’t been so bloody rude. My bill came to a little under $100 and I did not begrudge paying this as I had had both great pulpo and a most entertaining afternoon.

review_full: Fantastic!  An astonishing place where you can eat tapas standing. It looks like a butcher shop, but you eat also a very lovely fish. The tuna was unbelievable, tender like butter; the meat also something you have to try and just enjoy. No chance to describe the chuleton with truffle through words; also the crumbled eggs with truffle was unbelievable. Bacon with dates is wonderful; huge tomato with only oil and crumbled pepper so delicious and tasty; chipirones a la plancha one of the best ever tried; pulpo so good. To be done, there is also an incredible flan with mixed berries which is so delicious that, even if you already ate a lot, you cannot resist. The prices, compared to the quality, are not that high.

title_review: Special menu served inside - a great deal with superb food!
review_preview: On your first night in Madrid, we were not up for a major dinner, and walked around the circle near the Opera looking for something comfortable. Being from NYC, it's hard to deal with the cigarette smoke when eating outside. While the diners eating at...
review_full: On your first night in Madrid, we were not up for a major dinner, and walked around the circle near the Opera looking for something comfortable. Being from NYC, it's hard to deal with the cigarette smoke when eating outside.  While the diners eating at the restaurant's patio were having white linen service with all the extras, we ate inside, and ordered a simple belly of tuna salad with tomatoes, and the bar special which was also superb. 15 euros for a delicious chorizo sausage, a half chicken (both cooked right on the grill and served immediately), plus a salad and dessert.  The waitresses were friendly and made us feel very welcome. Highly recommended.

My main course was pasta filled with truffle, and ther was a lot of lovely black truffle in it. Perhaps I should not have chosen tiramisu for pudding as I wasn’t in Italy and it was a bit ordinary. Two small bottles of really nice liqueur then came. It was all a great experience.

review_preview: Desengaño is an unassuming place with very special food. Fusion would be the best description for the cuisine - a blend of tradition with new ingredients, flavors, and presentations. The vegetable tempura was light and flaky and accompanied with two unique and tasty aioli sauces;...
review_full: Desengaño is an unassuming place with very special food. Fusion would be the best description for the cuisine - a blend of tradition with new ingredients, flavors, and presentations. The vegetable tempura was light and flaky and accompanied with two unique and tasty aioli sauces; alcachofa consisted of marinated baby artichokes served with scallops and aioli; canneloni became peeled red pepper covering a delicious filling. This fusion and creativity flows through to the desserts. You can have many of these dishes as either tapas or full plates. There's a decent, if not broad wine selection and the service is very good. We returned for a second meal and were as pleased as we were on our first visit.

title_review: Just another good restaurant in Madrid
review_preview: Although the food is really nice and it deserves a 4-stars rating, I am giving 3 stars because I think there are also many great restaurants in Madrid like this one and I didn't see anything that stood up more here than in any of...
review_full: Although the food is really nice and it deserves a 4-stars rating, I am giving 3 stars because I think there are also many great restaurants in Madrid like this one and I didn't see anything that stood up more here than in any of the others. Besides, it was a bit expensive in my opinion for the quantity of food they serve, and there was a weird smell all over the place, like the smell of toilet freshener.  As I say, the food is really tasty and fancy. This is a place I would go if I am living in Madrid or if I have stayed in Madrid already for several weeks. However, I don't think it's a place to go if you are spending few days in Madrid. I would better go to other more traditional restaurants.

The food can be a bit interactive but we had a blast tweeting and mixing. We liked everything served, a highlight was a burrata and tomato dish- lovely and fresh. The octopus was nice, and a carpaccio-like beef and egg yolk concoction was tasty too. We had a wonderful time and truly nice entertaining service.  Really different and fun. It gets busy so book ahead or be prepared to line up ( or go at opening like we did ).

review_full: I will start by saying - this is a MUST for any foodie who loves seafood and is in Madrid. So this place is tiny and packed, but as soon as you get your spot - you're in heaven of seafood and a few other surprising tapas. It's not some luxury restaurant, but the food is rather expensive - and it's damn worth every single euro you spend there. Genius, simple, fresh and so delicious - this is what we had to say about every single dish we got. Another plus - this is the ONLY place in Madrid where we met a waiter who actually spoke good English! And that's quite a big deal when you want to understand what on earth are you ordering.  The whole place is pure fun and delight, and the concept of designing it all as a restaurant's kitchen is very cool.

review_preview: After a bitter experience at O'Reilleys restaurant the night before, I was pleasantly surprised at the difference in both quality and quantity of the food at this restaurant despite the slightly higher cost. As a general rule, I would advise that any bar or restaurant...
review_full: After a bitter experience at O'Reilleys restaurant the night before, I was pleasantly surprised at the difference in both quality and quantity of the food at this restaurant despite the slightly higher cost. As a general rule, I would advise that any bar or restaurant which requires publicity via the use of promoters to 'lure you in' (O'Reilleys being an example) should be avoided, as these are the poorer quality restaurants. This restaurant, alongside several others located on the same road do not need promoters or cheap deals, simply because they are good quality restaurants with high standards of food and service. Hence, I would recommend spending that extra 5-10 euros per person to ensure great food and top service.  The portions of tapas here were very large relative to other restaurants, hence offering good value for money; our waiter was so sincere, he had advised us when were over-ordering as we were unaware of portion sizes at time time, and he was spot on about how much food we would need!. He also gave us free olives and not one or two, but THREE portions of free bread to complement our delicious food; the most pleasant was the vegetarian soup with egg mixed with the fresh bread they gave us. In terms of drinks, I ordered a sangria for little over two euros which was absolutely divine, and a few of the others ordered a beer which they seemed content with.  Overall, the bill came to 44 Euros between 4 people including 1-2 alcoholic drinks each, fantastic service and great food. Remember, my rule 'if the club or restaurant has promoters and needs cheap deals, it cannot be focused on quality, but rather on volume and price' and you will enjoy some of the best cuisine Madrid has to offer!

title_review: What a Jem of a place to eat
review_preview: We walked around Madrid looking for a place to get paella at a reasonable price. Saw the daily special written on the entrance for Paella mixta for 6.50  Euros....that's a deal.  We went inside as all the outside tables were taken...probably a good idea as...
review_full: We walked around Madrid looking for a place to get paella at a reasonable price. Saw the daily special written on the entrance for Paella mixta for 6.50 Euros....that's a deal. We went inside as all the outside tables were taken...probably a good idea as it rained about 20 minutes later. We had a lovely waiteress that spoke english...We placed our order for 2 of the paella's one mixta and one with meat only as my wife is allergic to shell fish...After we ordered the waitress came back to inquire about the allergy, saying that the water they used for the rice was the same they used to cook the seafood and if there was an allergy, they would use plain water to cook the rice. We ordered a bottle of white wine....the house wine.. it was VERY good for 8.50 euros....along with the wine came a dish of green olives... The waitress told us that there was a 20 minute wait for paella....which was ok with us. When the food came it was served in individual paella dishes. The food was darned good. The mixta had a good amount of seafood, clams, mussels, shrip, and calamare. The other had plenty of chicken along with veggies.  After the entry we ordered Flan for desert... When we paid the bill, we were offered a complimentary liquor...Which was a great treat and a nice gesture....Of course we accepted. The service was good, the ambiance was good and the ;prices were very reasonable. Yes, we will go back, and yes we will recommed the restaurant to friends.

review_preview: With so many places to eat tapas, it is hard to find one that stands out.  We ate here a couple times because of the friendly wait staff, its good location that was off of the busy streets (no cars), and the reasonably priced and...
review_full: With so many places to eat tapas, it is hard to find one that stands out. We ate here a couple times because of the friendly wait staff, its good location that was off of the busy streets (no cars), and the reasonably priced and varied tapas. The second time we ate there we had a delicious paella, served as a tapa but large enough to feed two (more like a racione), freshly made for that serving (as opposed to being scooped out of a big pan made earlier) that included fresh prawns, shrimp, and other seafood, all for only 6 euros. Together with one other tapa, it made dinner. The clientele was a blend of tourists and locals. We always know we've found a good place to eat when we see locals there. As a side note that detracted from the experience, we ate outside both times and there was a steady stream of people coming by begging for money from all of the customers at the outside tables of all the restaurants, along with others selling flowers or other junk. We found it distracting and annoying and an invasion of the dining experience for which we were paying.

review_preview: We ate tonight at Densengano 13 based on other Tripadvisor users recommendations.  We were not disappointed.   The restaurant has two main sections, a bar where drinks and tapas can be purchased and a formal dining area.  We decided on a formal meal and can't comment...
review_full: We ate tonight at Densengano 13 based on other Tripadvisor users recommendations. We were not disappointed. The restaurant has two main sections, a bar where drinks and tapas can be purchased and a formal dining area. We decided on a formal meal and can't comment on the tapas section. The meal we had was excellent. For starters, my wife had a mixed salad with tuna (Salad Nicoise) and I had a clear consume soup with a hint of mint. Both were delicious. For the main course, she had Arroz de Marisco with clams, squid, mussels, and shrimp while I had Merluza con Almejas (Hake with clams cooked in a garlic broth). Again, both were delicious. The hake had a delicate flavor. Finally, for desert, we shared a Panchineta de Fresa which was a very delicate pastry surrounded by sauteed strawberries. With a glass of wine, two bottles of water, herbal tea and an expresso, the bill came to 54 euros. The restaurant has a wonderful formality to it. The decor is modernistic (black, white and silver) as are many newer European restaurants but with delightful photographs of Madrid buildings on the wall and a wall-size photo of New York's skyline. The atmosphere is quiet and private as the different tables are separated into sections. The meal was of high quality. We left feeling very good about the meal, something that I have learned is very important in evaluating a restaurant.

But in any event this is both a fun place, and somewhere to get some delicious food. Not much point in it if octopus is not you idea of a tasty dish, but if it is, you cannot fail to enjoy it. Octopus served in every possible way, even in croquettas. You can watch the beasties being snipped into bite sized pieces in a window onto the street . Plenty of excellent and cheap wines to wash it down. Salads and soups too if you wish, and the desserts are also more tempting than in many a Madrid establishment. Service friendly and efficient, and the bill at the end will bring a smile to your wallet and to you. Unmissable

review_preview: This restaurant is very easy going and with a friendly atmosphere. Located just few minutes walking from Puerta del Sol. We were enjoying our experience (apart some trouble to communicate with few member of staff who only speaks spanish), with some nice beer, very good...
review_full: This restaurant is very easy going and with a friendly atmosphere. Located just few minutes walking from Puerta del Sol. We were enjoying our experience (apart some trouble to communicate with few member of staff who only speaks spanish), with some nice beer, very good green peppers ,calamari and spanish chorizo. Our trouble start when the steak arrived, which were expecting it grilled and medium rare, and it came fried and rare. So with the communication trouble we ask it to have it grilled, but instead came back after 2 minutes the same steak which was most likely just microwaved (and became well done in the meantime). So we told them again that we don't want the steak in this conditions , and after few minutes the waitress told us that the chef was asking if we can choose something different from the menu !!! That was the first time in my life i heard of a chef restaurant not able to cook and asking the customer to order something different. After that our feeling about this place start changing, so we just wanted to leave, so kind of ruined the experience in this restaurant. It was a shame because we enjoyed the place and the spanish food, but cannot believe they are not able to cook a steak and just asking to order different stuff.

The waiter provided excellent recommendations from the dishes to choose, amount of food to order, wine to match etc. We had half servings of the Teryaki Salmon, Oxtail Canneloni, Veal cheek curry and the Steak (rare) - all were presented nicely and full of flavour. It was priced very affordably. We would highly recommend this place to anyone looking for an authentic, casual dinner in Madrid.

review_preview: My husband and I visited Desengano 13 for dinner on a Friday night having come across it in a fairly elderly article on the 10 best restaurants in Gran Via. I made my a reservation for 9.30 and we were greatly warmly on arrival, with...
review_full: My husband and I visited Desengano 13 for dinner on a Friday night having come across it in a fairly elderly article on the 10 best restaurants in Gran Via. I made my a reservation for 9.30 and we were greatly warmly on arrival, with the restaurant still pretty quiet.  Our waiter showed us to a table in the front of the restaurant, but promptly picked up on my husband's mobility issues and offered us a table in the back with a more solid dining chair, which was much appreciated.  We ordered a selection of dishes from their new menu, including two types of croquette, scrambled eggs with jam on and black truffle, octopus with potato foam and red curry and oxtail cannelloni. The dishes were a joy, and we thoroughly enjoyed every one, though the stand out for me was the octopus dish which was quite simply the best I've ever eaten. The ham, eggs and truffle ran it a very close second.  We enjoyed 3 beers and a glass of Rioja, along with bread and olives with our dinner, and were very pleasantly surprised at the bill, which came to €50.  We loved our evening at Desengano 13; the service was warm, friendly and attentive and our waiter was happy to discuss the dishes and wine list with us. I would most definitely return and am actually drooling as I write about the heavenly octopus dish.  Thanks to the team at Desengano for a fabulous dinner in Madrid, we hope to return again soon.

review_preview: We were in Madrid for one night and stayed close to Gran Via (Petit Palace Ducal - review to follow). We looked online for places to eat near Gran Via and came across Desengano 13. Only a couple of blocks off of Gran Via and...
review_full: We were in Madrid for one night and stayed close to Gran Via (Petit Palace Ducal - review to follow). We looked online for places to eat near Gran Via and came across Desengano 13. Only a couple of blocks off of Gran Via and what a great place. We went there around 6pm just before our 8pm Flamenco show (Cafe de Chinitas - review to follow). We were the only ones there during that time. The staff was great. Had 4 glasses of wine, an appetizer, one side, 2 entrees and one dessert for around 70 Euros. Had the mozzarella appetizer and mushroom side. Both were very tasty. My fiancée had the oxtail and I had the ribs (pics below). Both were delicious but the oxtail had a better presentation and unique taste. The house red was awesome (pic below). This was the best meal we had while in Spain and one of the most memorable meals we had while in Europe. Overall, great restaurant, unique flavors with reasonable prices

review_full: Really enjoyed our meal here. We went in early on the first night we arrived. There was good choice on the menu, with a good balance between vegetarian and meat dishes, It was possible to have Tapas or full portion sizes. We had good fun with the staff when there was a mix up with the order - a mixture of our bad Spanish and there reasonable English! We were treated well. I would recommend this if you want Tapas, a quick drink or an early meal.

review_preview: Looking for a local place open for dinner before 8 PM.  Friendly staff, very helpful to us English speakers, and outstanding food. Had three 1/2 orders of fish dishes and ordered 2 more and desert because all were so good. Highly recommend.
